inter_results.nl_code:
What is a special guardian

You can apply to be a child’s special guardian when they cannot live with their birth parents and adoption is not right for them.

if a child cannot live with their birth parents and adoption is not suitable, you can apply to be their special guardian

You’ll be responsible for looking after the child until they’re 18 (unless the court takes your responsibility away earlier).

Key concept: responsible for child until 18

You’ll make all day to day decisions about the child, for example schooling and medical treatment. You do not have to discuss these decisions with the birth parents.

Key concept: make day to day decisions

You’ll need to get the consent of everyone who has parental responsibility for the child before you make some important decisions, for example:

  • changing the child’s surname
  • putting the child up for adoption
  • taking the child abroad for more than 3 months
  • the child having surgery for reasons other than improving health, such as circumcision, sterilisation or cosmetic surgery
    • if you need consent for important decisions, you must get the consent of everyone who has parental responsibility for the child. This includes decisions such as changing the child's surname, putting the child up for adoption, taking the child abroad for more than 3 months, and the child having surgery for non-health reasons.

    If you cannot get consent, you can ask the court to decide. Use the form ‘Make an application in existing court proceedings related to children’ (form C2).

    if you cannot get consent, you can ask the court to make the decision. You can use the form 'Make an application in existing court proceedings related to children' (form C2).

    After you apply

    Within 10 days of receiving your application the court will send you a case number and a date for a meeting to set out:

  • a timetable for your case
  • how it will be dealt with
    • if you receive your application, the court will send you a case number and a date for a meeting within 10 days. This meeting is called a 'first directions hearing'.

    You must go to all hearings you’re told to unless the court excuses you. If you’re not able to go, contact the court office.

    Key concept: attend all hearings unless excused if you are told to attend a hearing, you must go unless the court excuses you. If you are unable to attend, contact the court office.
inter_results.full_response:
Within 10 days of receiving your application the court will send you a case number and a date for a meeting to set out:

  • a timetable for your case
  • how it will be dealt with
    • Answer: within 10 days

Overview

To be adopted, a child must:

  • be under the age of 18 when the adoption application is made
  • not be (or have never been) married or in a civil partnership
    • if the child is under 18 and not married or in a civil partnership, they are eligible for adoption

    Who can adopt a child

    You may be able to adopt a child if you’re aged 21 or over (there’s no upper age limit) and either:

  • single
  • married
  • in a civil partnership
  • an unmarried couple (same sex and opposite sex)
  • the partner of the child’s parent
    • if you are aged 21 or over and single or married or in a civil partnership or an unmarried couple or the partner of the child's parent, you are eligible to adopt a child

    There are different rules for private adoptions and adoptions of looked-after children.

    if it is a private adoption, the rules for private adoption apply if it is an adoption of looked-after children, the rules for looked-after children adoption apply
inter_results.full_response:
You may be able to adopt a child if you’re aged 21 or over (there’s no upper age limit)

Answer: no

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

If you’re severely disabled as a result of a vaccination against certain diseases, you could get a one-off tax-free payment of £120,000. This is called a Vaccine Damage Payment.

if you're severely disabled due to a vaccination, you may be eligible for a Vaccine Damage Payment of £120,000

Eligibility

You could get a payment if you’re severely disabled and your disability was caused by vaccination against any of the following diseases:

  • coronavirus (COVID-19)
  • diphtheria
  • haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
  • human papillomavirus
  • influenza, except for influenza caused by a pandemic influenza virus
  • measles
  • meningococcal group B (meningitis B)
  • meningococcal group C (meningitis C)
  • meningococcal group W (meningitis W)
  • mumps
  • pandemic influenza A (H1N1) 2009 (swine flu) - up to 31 August 2010
  • pertussis (whooping cough)
  • pneumococcal infection
  • poliomyelitis
  • rotavirus
  • rubella (German measles)
  • smallpox - up to 1 August 1971
  • tetanus
  • tuberculosis (TB)
    • if you're severely disabled due to any of these diseases, you may be eligible for a Vaccine Damage Payment

    You may have had a combined vaccination against a number of the diseases listed. For example, you might have been vaccinated against DTP (diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis) or MMR (measles, mumps and rubella).

    Key concept: combined vaccination possible

    You may also be able to get a payment if you’re severely disabled because either:

  • your mother was vaccinated against one of the diseases in the list while she was pregnant
  • you’ve been in close physical contact with someone who’s had an oral vaccine against poliomyelitis
    • if you're severely disabled due to either of these reasons, you may be eligible for a Vaccine Damage Payment

    What counts as ‘severely disabled’

    Disablement is worked out as a percentage, and ‘severe disablement’ means at least 60% disabled.

    if your disablement percentage is at least 60%, you are considered severely disabled

    This could be a mental or physical disablement and will be based on medical evidence from the doctors or hospitals involved in your treatment.

    Key concept: medical evidence required

    When and where the vaccination must have taken place

    You must normally have been vaccinated before your 18th birthday, unless the vaccination was during an outbreak of disease in the UK or the Isle of Man, or it was against:

  • coronavirus (COVID-19)
  • poliomyelitis
  • rubella
  • meningococcal group C
  • human papillomavirus
  • pandemic influenza A (H1N1) 2009 (swine flu)
  • meningococcal group W before your 26th birthday
  • influenza
    • if you were vaccinated before your 18th birthday or during an outbreak of disease or against any of these specific diseases, you may be eligible for a Vaccine Damage Payment

    The vaccination must have been given in the UK or the Isle of Man, unless you were vaccinated as part of your armed forces medical treatment.

    if the vaccination was given in the UK or the Isle of Man or as part of your armed forces medical treatment, you may be eligible for a Vaccine Damage Payment
inter_results.full_response:
If you’re severely disabled as a result of a vaccination against certain diseases, you could get a one-off tax-free payment of £120,000. This is called a Vaccine Damage Payment.

You could get a payment if you’re severely disabled and your disability was caused by vaccination against any of the following diseases:

  • coronavirus (COVID-19)
    • Answer: yes

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

You don’t usually pay tax on anything you inherit at the time you inherit it.

Key concept: no tax on inherited assets at time of inheritance

You may need to pay:

  • Income Tax on profit you later earn from your inheritance, eg dividends from shares or rental income from a property
    • Key concept: income tax on profit from inheritance
  • Capital Gains Tax if you later sell shares or a property you inherited
    • Key concept: capital gains tax on sale of inherited assets
  • Inheritance Tax
    • Key concept: inheritance tax

    Selling the property

    You don’t pay Capital Gains Tax when you sell your home. You do pay it if you make a profit when you sell a property that isn’t your main home.

    if you sell your main home, you don't pay capital gains tax on the sale if you sell a property that isn't your main home and make a profit, you pay capital gains tax on the sale

    If inheriting a property means you own 2 homes, you’ll have to nominate one of them as your main home. You must tell HMRC which property is your main home within 2 years of inheriting the property.

    if you inherit a property and own 2 homes, you must nominate one of them as your main home and tell HMRC within 2 years

    If you don’t tell HMRC and you sell one of the properties, they’ll decide which property was your main home.

    if you don't tell HMRC and sell one of the properties, HMRC will decide which property was your main home
inter_results.full_response:
If inheriting a property means you own 2 homes, you’ll have to nominate one of them as your main home. You must tell HMRC which property is your main home within 2 years of inheriting the property.

If you don’t tell HMRC and you sell one of the properties, they’ll decide which property was your main home.

Answer: yes

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

You and your partner may be able to take time off work if your child dies before they turn 18, or if you have a stillbirth after 24 weeks of pregnancy.

if your child dies before they turn 18 or you have a stillbirth after 24 weeks of pregnancy, you may be eligible for leave or pay

The death or stillbirth must have happened on or after 6 April 2020.

Key concept: death or stillbirth after 6 April 2020

This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

Key concept: guide available in Welsh

You might be able to get leave, pay or both. You may be eligible for:

  • Parental Bereavement Leave
    • Key concept: eligible for parental bereavement leave
  • Statutory Parental Bereavement Pay
    • Key concept: eligible for statutory parental bereavement pay

    There’s rules about when you can take your leave and pay and how to claim.

    Key concept: rules about leave and pay

    You can only claim Statutory Parental Bereavement Pay and Leave if you’re employed in England, Scotland or Wales.

    if you are employed in England, Scotland or Wales, you are eligible for statutory parental bereavement pay and leave

    Parental Bereavement Leave

    You can take 2 weeks’ leave from the first day of your employment for each child who has died or was stillborn if you’re eligible.

    if you are eligible for leave, you can take 2 weeks' leave

    You can take:

  • 2 weeks together
    • Key concept: take 2 weeks together
  • 2 separate weeks of leave
    • Key concept: take 2 separate weeks of leave
  • only one week of leave
    • Key concept: take 1 week of leave

    A week is the same number of days that you normally work in a week.

    Key concept: a week is the same number of days as you normally work

    The leave:

  • can start on or after the date of the death or stillbirth
    • Key concept: leave can start after the date of the death or stillbirth
  • must finish within 56 weeks of the date of the death or stillbirth
    • Key concept: leave must finish within 56 weeks of the date of the death or stillbirth

    If you were the child’s parent or a parent’s partner

    You may be eligible if at the time of the child’s death or stillbirth, you were:

  • the child or baby’s parent - either biological, adoptive or parent of a child born to a surrogate
    • Key concept: eligible if you were the child or baby's parent
  • the partner of the child or baby’s parent
    • Key concept: eligible if you were the partner of the child or baby's parent

    Biological parents of the child or baby will not be eligible for Parental Bereavement Leave and Statutory Parental Bereavement Pay after an adoption or parental order was made, unless there was a contact order in place.

    if you are a biological parent and an adoption or parental order was made, you will not be eligible for parental bereavement leave and statutory parental bereavement pay, unless there was a contact order in place.
inter_results.full_response:
You and your partner may be able to take time off work if your child dies before they turn 18, or if you have a stillbirth after 24 weeks of pregnancy.

You might be able to get leave, pay or both. You may be eligible for:

  • Parental Bereavement Leave
  • Statutory Parental Bereavement Pay

    • You can only claim Statutory Parental Bereavement Pay and Leave if you’re employed in England, Scotland or Wales.

    If you were the child’s parent or a parent’s partner

    You may be eligible if at the time of the child’s death or stillbirth, you were:

  • the child or baby’s parent - either biological, adoptive or parent of a child born to a surrogate
  • the partner of the child or baby’s parent

    • Biological parents of the child or baby will not be eligible for Parental Bereavement Leave and Statutory Parental Bereavement Pay after an adoption or parental order was made, unless there was a contact order in place.

    Answer: yes

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

You don’t usually pay tax on anything you inherit at the time you inherit it.

Key concept: no tax on inherited items at time of inheritance

You may need to pay:

  • Income Tax on profit you later earn from your inheritance, eg dividends from shares or rental income from a property
    • Key concept: income tax on profit from inheritance
  • Capital Gains Tax if you later sell shares or a property you inherited
    • Key concept: capital gains tax on sale of inherited shares or property
  • Inheritance Tax
    • Key concept: inheritance tax

    Inheritance Tax

    The estate of the person who died usually pays Inheritance Tax. You may need to pay Inheritance Tax if the estate can’t or doesn’t pay it.

    Key concept: estate pays inheritance tax if the estate cannot or does not pay inheritance tax, you may need to pay inheritance tax

    You may need to pay Inheritance Tax on a gift the person gave you in the 7 years before they died.

    Key concept: inheritance tax on gift within 7 years before death

    You may also need to pay it if your inheritance is put into a trust and the trust can’t or doesn’t pay.

    Key concept: inheritance tax if inheritance put into trust and trust cannot or does not pay

    If the will says the Inheritance Tax should be paid out of the assets you’ve inherited, the executor of the will or administrator of the estate will usually pay it.

    Key concept: executor or administrator pays inheritance tax if will says it should be paid from inherited assets

    HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) will contact you if you need to pay.

    Key concept: HMRC contacts if need to pay inheritance tax

    Money and shares

    In most cases you don’t pay any tax on money and shares when you inherit them.

    Key concept: no tax on inherited money and shares

    Inheritance Tax

    You may have to pay Inheritance Tax on money and shares you inherit if the deceased person’s estate can’t or doesn’t pay.

    if the estate cannot or does not pay inheritance tax, you may need to pay inheritance tax on money and shares

    HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) will contact you if you need to pay.

    Key concept: HMRC contacts if need to pay inheritance tax on money and shares

    Any money or shares the person gave you before they died are known as gifts and have different rules.

    Key concept: gifts have different rules
inter_results.full_response:
You don’t usually pay tax on anything you inherit at the time you inherit it.

You may need to pay Inheritance Tax on a gift the person gave you in the 7 years before they died.

You may also need to pay it if your inheritance is put into a trust and the trust can’t or doesn’t pay.

If the will says the Inheritance Tax should be paid out of the assets you’ve inherited, the executor of the will or administrator of the estate will usually pay it.

In most cases you don’t pay any tax on money and shares when you inherit them.

You may have to pay Inheritance Tax on money and shares you inherit if the deceased person’s estate can’t or doesn’t pay.

Answer: It is uncertain whether you have to pay inheritance tax on your windfall.

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

Attendance Allowance helps with extra costs if you have a disability severe enough that you need someone to help look after you.

Key concept: Attendance Allowance helps with extra costs

This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

Key concept: guide available in Welsh

It’s paid at 2 different rates and how much you get depends on the level of care that you need because of your disability.

Key concept: paid at 2 rates

You could get £60 or £89.60 a week to help with personal support if you’re both:

  • physically or mentally disabled
  • State Pension age or older
    • Key concept: eligible for Attendance Allowance Key concept: does not cover mobility needs

    The other benefits you get can increase if you get Attendance Allowance.

    Key concept: other benefits can increase with Attendance Allowance

    You do not have to have someone caring for you in order to claim.

    Key concept: do not have to have a carer to claim

    If you do have a carer, they could get Carer’s Allowance if you have substantial caring needs.

    Key concept: carer eligible for Carer's Allowance

    Attendance Allowance rates

    Rate | Level of help you need Lower rate - £60 | Frequent help or constant supervision during the day, or supervision at night Higher rate - £89.60 | Help or supervision throughout both day and night, or you’re terminally ill if you need frequent help or constant supervision during the day, or supervision at night, you can get Attendance Allowance at a rate of £60 if you need help or supervision throughout both day and night, or you're terminally ill, you can get Attendance Allowance at a rate of £89.60

    If your circumstances change, you could get a different rate. You must report a change of circumstances.

    Key concept: report change of circumstances

    You could get extra Pension Credit, Housing Benefit or Council Tax Reduction if you get Attendance Allowance - check with the helpline or office dealing with your benefit.

    Key concept: eligible for extra Pension Credit Key concept: eligible for Housing Benefit Key concept: eligible for Council Tax Reduction
inter_results.full_response:
<tr>Lower rate - £60 | Frequent help or constant supervision during the day, or supervision at night</tr>
Answer: £60

answers:
tax exemption up to £10,000 earnings from fostering

On top of the £10,000 exemption, you also get tax relief for every week (or part week) that a child is in your care.

inter_results.nl_code:
Training and development

You need to complete the training, support, and development standards workbook within 12 months of being approved to foster.

Key concept: complete training workbook within 12 months

Contact your fostering service to find out what other training and development is available. They should help you:

  • with a personal development plan
  • take part in learning and development sessions
    • Key concept: contact fostering service for additional training and development Key concept: personal development plan available Key concept: learning and development sessions available

    The Foster Carers’ Charter explains your rights as a foster parent.

    Key concept: Foster Carers' Charter explains rights

    You do not have a statutory right to time off work to care for foster children.

    Key concept: no statutory right to time off work for foster care

    If you’re fostering for adoption you’ll be entitled to adoption pay and leave from when the child comes to live with you.

    if you are fostering for adoption, you are entitled to adoption pay and leave from when the child comes to live with you

    If you’re considering fostering, find out about becoming a foster parent.

    Key concept: considering fostering

    Tax arrangements

    You should have registered as self-employed when you started to foster. You’ll need to file tax returns. Check with your fostering service what you need to do.

    Key concept: registered as self-employed Key concept: file tax returns

    In your tax return, you’ll be able to claim:

  • a tax exemption of up to £10,000 per household
  • tax relief for every week you foster a child
    • Key concept: claim tax exemption up to £10,000 per household Key concept: claim tax relief for every week of fostering

    This is known as qualifying care relief.

    Key concept: qualifying care relief

    You may be entitled to National Insurance credits, which count towards your State Pension.

    Key concept: entitled to National Insurance credits

    Tax exemption

    In a tax year, households do not pay tax on the first £10,000 they earn from fostering. You’ll still pay tax on money you earn from a job or investment.

    Key concept: tax exemption up to £10,000 earnings from fostering

    Tax relief

    On top of the £10,000 exemption, you also get tax relief for every week (or part week) that a child is in your care. This means you do not have to pay tax on some of your earnings over £10,000.

Overview

You can help make or make decisions about someone’s property and money if they appointed you using an enduring power of attorney (EPA).

if you were appointed using an enduring power of attorney (EPA), you can help make or make decisions about someone's property and money

The person who appointed you is called the ‘donor’ - you are their ‘attorney’.

Key concept: donor appointed you as attorney

Any decision you make on the donor’s behalf must be in their best interests.

Key concept: decision must be in best interests

You’ll need to check if the donor’s given you specific instructions or guidance in the EPA document that will affect your responsibilities.

Key concept: check for specific instructions in EPA

Only EPAs made and signed before October 1, 2007 can still be used. After that date donors had to make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) instead.

Key concept: EPA before October 2007 can be used

This guide is also available in Welsh.

Key concept: guide available in Welsh

Using the enduring power of attorney

You can start using an EPA at any time if the EPA is legal and the donor gives you permission.

Key concept: can start using EPA with legal EPA and donor permission

You’ll be responsible for helping the donor make decisions about their finances. Depending on their instructions you’ll help manage things like their:

  • money and bills
    • Key concept: help manage money and bills
  • bank and building society accounts
    • Key concept: help manage bank and building society accounts
  • property and investments
    • Key concept: help manage property and investments
  • pensions and benefits
    • Key concept: help manage pensions and benefits

    There may be other attorneys - if there are, check how the donor wants you to make decisions.

    if there are other attorneys, check how the donor wants you to make decisions

    You must register the EPA when the donor starts to lose or has lost their mental capacity. This means they cannot make a decision at the time it needs to be made because of a mental impairment.

    Key concept: register EPA when donor loses mental capacity

    You must still involve the person in making decisions whenever possible and only make decisions on their behalf which are in their best interests.

    Key concept: involve person in decisions when possible Key concept: decisions must be in best interests

    Check an enduring power is legal

    You can only use an enduring power of attorney (EPA) if it was made correctly.

    Key concept: can use EPA if made correctly

    Check that the EPA form was:

  • made when the donor was at least 18 and had the ability to make their own decisions (they had not lost ‘mental capacity’)
    • Key concept: EPA form made when donor was at least 18 and had ability to make decisions
  • signed by the donor and a witness who was not one of the attorneys for the EPA
    • Key concept: EPA form signed by donor and witness not attorney
  • signed by all the attorneys
    • Key concept: EPA form signed by all attorneys

    When the EPA was made you and any other attorneys had to be:

  • 18 or over
    • Key concept: attorneys 18 or over
  • not bankrupt - and have not been bankrupt since
    • Key concept: attorneys not bankrupt

    Only EPAs made and signed before October 1, 2007 can still be used. After that date donors had to make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) instead.

    Key concept: EPA before October 2007 can be used

    When there's more than one attorney

    if there is more than one attorney, check the EPA form to find out the number of attorneys appointed

    If there’s more than one attorney, check whether you must make decisions:

  • separately or together (sometimes called ‘jointly and severally’), which means you can make decisions on your own or with other attorneys
    • if there is more than one attorney, check how to make decisions separately or together
  • together (sometimes called ‘jointly’), which means you and all the other attorneys have to agree on a decision
    • if there is more than one attorney, check how to make decisions together

    The donor may give instructions for you to make some decisions ‘jointly’ and others ‘jointly and severally’.

    if the donor gives instructions, there may be some decisions to make jointly and others jointly and severally

    Attorneys who are appointed jointly must all agree or they cannot make the decision.

    if attorneys are appointed jointly, all attorneys must agree to make a decision

Any decision you make on the donor’s behalf must be in their best interests.

You’ll need to check if the donor’s given you specific instructions or guidance in the EPA document that will affect your responsibilities.

answers: the donor, their family members, and other attorneys

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

You can help make or make decisions about someone’s property and money if they appointed you using an enduring power of attorney (EPA).

Key concept: can help with property and money using EPA

The person who appointed you is called the ‘donor’ - you are their ‘attorney’.

Key concept: donor appointed attorney

Any decision you make on the donor’s behalf must be in their best interests.

Key concept: decisions must be in best interests

You’ll need to check if the donor’s given you specific instructions or guidance in the EPA document that will affect your responsibilities.

Key concept: check for specific instructions or guidance in EPA

Only EPAs made and signed before October 1, 2007 can still be used. After that date donors had to make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) instead.

Key concept: EPAs before October 2007 can still be used

This guide is also available in Welsh.

Key concept: guide available in Welsh

Register an enduring power of attorney

You must register the enduring power of attorney (EPA) as soon as the donor starts to lose mental capacity.

Key concept: register EPA when donor loses mental capacity
  • Tell the donor, their family members and other attorneys you intend to register the EPA.
    • Key concept: tell people you intend to register EPA
  • Apply to register the EPA.
    • Key concept: apply to register EPA
  • Pay the fee.
    • Key concept: pay registration fee

    Telling people you intend to register

    Download and fill in form EP1PG. Send it to:

  • the donor
  • at least 3 of the donor’s family members who are eligible - they must be 18 or over and have mental capacity
  • any attorneys who were appointed ‘jointly and severally’ but are not applying to register the EPA
    • Key concept: tell people you intend to register EPA

    You must tell the first 3 eligible family members from the following list. If there’s no family member in a particular category, move on to the next one. You must try to tell the family members in this order:

  • donor’s husband, wife or civil partner
  • donor’s children (including adopted children but not including stepchildren)
  • donor’s parents
  • donor’s brothers and sisters (including half-brothers and half-sisters)
  • widow or widower or surviving civil partner of the donor’s child
  • donor’s grandchildren
  • donor’s nephews and nieces (children of the donor’s full brothers and sisters)
  • donor’s nephews and nieces (children of the donor’s half-brothers and half-sisters)
  • donor’s aunts and uncles (full brothers or sisters of a parent of the donor)
  • donor’s first cousins (children of the donor’s aunts and uncles who are full brothers and sisters of a parent of the donor)
    • Key concept: tell family members in order

    You must tell all the people in a category if you tell one of them, eg if 1 of the 3 relatives you’re telling is a grandchild and the donor has 15 other grandchildren, you must tell all 16 of them.

    Key concept: tell all people in category

    If you’re a family member as well as an attorney, you count as one of the people to be told. You’ll still have to tell other people in your category.

    Key concept: if you're a family member and attorney, you count as one person to be told

    You must do all you can to find the people you’re telling. If you cannot find their address, or if there are not 3 relatives alive, tell the Office of the Public Guardian when you apply to register.

    Key concept: do all you can to find people to be told

    People who you tell can object to the registration. They have 35 days to object from when they get the form.

    Key concept: people told can object within 35 days
inter_results.full_response:
• Tell the donor, their family members and other attorneys you intend to register the EPA.
    • Answer: the donor, their family members, and other attorneys

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

You can help make or make decisions about someone’s property and money if they appointed you using an enduring power of attorney (EPA).

Key concept: can help make decisions with EPA

The person who appointed you is called the ‘donor’ - you are their ‘attorney’.

Key concept: donor appointed attorney

Any decision you make on the donor’s behalf must be in their best interests.

Key concept: decisions must be in best interests

You’ll need to check if the donor’s given you specific instructions or guidance in the EPA document that will affect your responsibilities.

Key concept: check for specific instructions or guidance in EPA

Only EPAs made and signed before October 1, 2007 can still be used. After that date donors had to make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) instead.

Key concept: EPA made before October 2007 can still be used

This guide is also available in Welsh.

Key concept: guide available in Welsh

Check an enduring power is legal

You can only use an enduring power of attorney (EPA) if it was made correctly.

Key concept: EPA can only be used if made correctly

Check that the EPA form was:

  • made when the donor was at least 18 and had the ability to make their own decisions (they had not lost ‘mental capacity’)
    • Key concept: EPA form made correctly if donor was at least 18 and had the ability to make their own decisions
  • signed by the donor and a witness who was not one of the attorneys for the EPA
    • Key concept: EPA form signed correctly if signed by donor and witness
  • signed by all the attorneys
    • Key concept: EPA form signed correctly if signed by all attorneys

    When the EPA was made you and any other attorneys had to be:

  • 18 or over
    • Key concept: attorneys age at least 18
  • not bankrupt - and have not been bankrupt since
    • Key concept: attorneys not bankrupt

    Only EPAs made and signed before October 1, 2007 can still be used. After that date donors had to make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) instead.

    Key concept: EPA made before October 2007 can still be used
inter_results.full_response:
You can help make or make decisions about someone’s property and money if they appointed you using an enduring power of attorney (EPA).

Any decision you make on the donor’s behalf must be in their best interests.

You’ll need to check if the donor’s given you specific instructions or guidance in the EPA document that will affect your responsibilities.

Answer: yes

inter_results.nl_code:
Eligibility

Housing Benefit can help you pay your rent if you’re unemployed, on a low income or claiming benefits. It’s being replaced by Universal Credit.

Key concept: eligible for Housing Benefit

You can only make a new claim for Housing Benefit if either of the following apply:

if you have reached State Pension age or are in supported, sheltered, or temporary housing, you can make a new claim for Housing Benefit

If you’re over State Pension age and live with your partner

You can make a new claim for Housing Benefit if any of the following apply:

if you are over State Pension age and live with your partner, you can make a new claim for Housing Benefit if both of you have reached State Pension age or if one of you has reached State Pension age and claimed Pension Credit before 15 May 2019, or if you are in supported, sheltered, or temporary housing

If you’re in supported, sheltered, or temporary housing

You can make a new claim if:

if you are in supported, sheltered, or temporary housing, you can make a new claim for Housing Benefit if you are living in temporary accommodation, living in a refuge for domestic abuse, or living in sheltered or supported housing with care support or supervision

If you do not get ‘care, support, or supervision’ through your supported or sheltered housing, you can apply for Universal Credit to help with housing costs.

if you are in supported or sheltered housing without care support or supervision, you can apply for Universal Credit to help with housing costs

If you’re in supported, sheltered, or temporary housing, you can apply for Universal Credit to help with other living costs.

if you are in supported, sheltered, or temporary housing, you can apply for Universal Credit to help with other living costs
inter_results.full_response:
You can make a new claim for Housing Benefit if you’re unemployed, on a low income or claiming benefits.

If you’re in supported, sheltered, or temporary housing, you can make a new claim for Housing Benefit if you are living in temporary accommodation, living in a refuge for domestic abuse, or living in sheltered or supported housing with care support or supervision.

Answer: yes

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

You may need to manage a Court Funds Office account for someone if you’re their property and affairs deputy and you’re authorised by the Court of Protection to look after money on their behalf.

if you are a property and affairs deputy, you can manage a Court Funds Office account for someone

Check the court order that appointed you as deputy - it tells you what you’re authorised to do.

Key concept: check court order for authority

You’ll need to apply on behalf of the person you’re deputy for to:

  • manage an account that was opened for them by court order, for example for money they received from a court case
    • Key concept: manage existing account
  • open an account for them
    • Key concept: open new account

    They’ll get a special account with the Court Funds Office.

    Key concept: special account with Court Funds Office

    Your responsibilities

    The account belongs to the person you’re deputy for. You’re the only person who can manage it on their behalf.

    Key concept: account belongs to person you are deputy for

    You must keep to your responsibilities as a deputy when you’re managing the account.

    Key concept: keep to responsibilities as deputy

    Check the court order that appointed you as deputy - it tells you the limits on what you can and cannot do with the account.

    Key concept: check court order for limits

    Apply

    You need to apply to:

  • open an account for someone
  • manage an account for someone
    • Key concept: apply to open or manage account

    You must be appointed by the Court of Protection as the person’s property and affairs deputy.

    Key concept: appointed by Court of Protection as deputy

    If your application is successful, you’ll be able to make withdrawals from the bank account that you run on behalf of the person whose affairs you manage.

    if your application is successful, you'll be able to make withdrawals from the bank account
  • Check the details on the court order that appointed you as deputy - you’ll need the date of the order and the case number.
    • Key concept: check details on court order
  • Fill in form CFO A to apply for authority to make withdrawals - give your bank account details and tick the ‘New details’ box.
    • Key concept: fill in form CFO A
  • Attach a copy of your bank statement (less than 3 months old) or a letter from your bank to confirm your bank account details.
    • Key concept: attach bank statement or letter
  • Fill in form CFO L to pay money in to the account at the same time as applying - attach a cheque made payable to the ‘Accountant General of the Senior Courts’.
    • Key concept: fill in form CFO L
  • Send forms and attachments together with a copy of the original court order that appointed you as deputy - it must have a seal. The address is on the forms.
    • Key concept: send forms, attachments, and copy of court order

    You’ll get a letter from the Court Funds Office within 5 working days to confirm that you’re set up to manage the account.

    Key concept: confirmation letter within 5 working days

    Your form will be returned if your application cannot be processed - you’ll be told what you can do to fix this.

    if your application cannot be processed, your form will be returned with instructions to fix

    Stop managing or close an account

    A new deputy can take over management of the account if you stop being a deputy or die.

    if you stop being a deputy or die, a new deputy can take over management of the account

    You cannot hand over management of the account - only the Court of Protection can appoint a new deputy. The new deputy will then need to apply to manage the account.

    Key concept: cannot hand over management of account

    You stop being a deputy

    Tell the Court Funds Office in writing if you stop being a deputy - send a copy of the letter to the Office of the Public Guardian and Court of Protection.

    if you stop being a deputy, notify the Court Funds Office in writing and send a copy of the letter to the Office of the Public Guardian and Court of Protection
inter_results.full_response:
A new deputy can take over management of the account if you stop being a deputy or die.

You cannot hand over management of the account - only the Court of Protection can appoint a new deputy. The new deputy will then need to apply to manage the account.

Answer: no

  • with a personal development plan

    • Key concept: contact fostering service for training and development Key concept: personal development plan available Key concept: learning and development sessions available

    The Foster Carers’ Charter explains your rights as a foster parent.

    You do not have a statutory right to time off work to care for foster children.

    If you’re fostering for adoption you’ll be entitled to adoption pay and leave from when the child comes to live with you.

    If you’re considering fostering, find out about becoming a foster parent.

    Making decisions for your foster child

    Your foster child’s placement plan should tell you what decisions you can make, known as delegated authority.

    Key concept: placement plan indicates delegated authority

    There are 3 different levels to delegated authority:

  • day-to-day decisions like dental check ups, hair cuts, school trips, parent-teacher meetings and letting your child go to sleepovers
  • long-term decisions like which school a child goes to
  • significant decisions made by the local authority and birth parents, like surgery
    • Key concept: delegated authority levels

    If your child’s placement plan does not tell you what level of delegated authority you have you should contact your fostering service to find out.

    You may not have the same level of authority for each child you foster. For example, you might foster 2 children and have the right to sign a consent form for one of them.

    Key concept: different authority levels for each foster child

  • a medical examination
  • local or general anaesthetic

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

Special educational needs and disabilities (SEND) can affect a child or young person’s ability to learn. They can affect their:

  • behaviour or ability to socialise, for example they struggle to make friends
  • reading and writing, for example because they have dyslexia
  • ability to understand things
  • concentration levels, for example because they have ADHD
  • physical ability
    • if a child or young person has special educational needs and disabilities, it can affect their behaviour or ability to socialise, reading and writing, ability to understand things, concentration levels, and physical ability

    Who to talk to

    If you think your child may have special educational needs, contact the SEN co-ordinator, or ‘SENCO’ in your child’s school or nursery.

    if your child is in a school or nursery, contact the SENCO

    Contact your local council if your child is not in a school or nursery.

    if your child is not in a school or nursery, contact your local council

    Your local Information, Advice and Support (IAS) Service can give you advice about SEND.

    contact the IAS Service

    Support your child can receive

    Your child may be eligible for:

  • SEN support - support given in school, like speech therapy
  • an education, health and care (EHC) plan - a plan of care for children and young people aged up to 25 who have more complex needs
    • if your child has special educational needs, they may be eligible for SEN support and an education, health and care (EHC) plan

    If you or your child got support before September 2014 this will continue until your local council changes it to an EHC plan.

    if you or your child received support before September 2014, it will continue until your local council changes it to an EHC plan

    Children under 5

    SEN support for children under 5 includes:

  • a written progress check when your child is 2 years old
  • a child health visitor carrying out a health check for your child if they’re aged 2 to 3
  • a written assessment in the summer term of your child’s first year of primary school
  • making reasonable adjustments for disabled children, like providing aids like tactile signs
    • SEN support for children under 5 includes a written progress check at 2 years old, a health check by a child health visitor at 2 to 3 years old, a written assessment in the summer term of the child's first year of primary school, and making reasonable adjustments for disabled children

    Nurseries, playgroups and childminders registered with Ofsted follow the Early Years Foundation Stage (EYFS) framework. The framework makes sure that there’s support in place for children with SEND.

    nurseries, playgroups, and childminders registered with Ofsted follow the Early Years Foundation Stage (EYFS) framework to provide support for children with SEND

    Talk to a doctor or health adviser if you think your child has SEND but they do not go to a nursery, playgroup, or childminder. They’ll tell you what support options are available.

    if your child does not go to a nursery, playgroup, or childminder, talk to a doctor or health adviser to explore available support options

    Extra help

    An education, health and care (EHC) plan is for children and young people aged up to 25 who need more support than is available through special educational needs support.

    An education, health and care (EHC) plan is available for children and young people aged up to 25 who require more support than what is provided through special educational needs support

    EHC plans identify educational, health and social needs and set out the additional support to meet those needs.

    EHC plans identify educational, health, and social needs and outline the additional support required to meet those needs

The Coastguard Rescue Service is made up of volunteers and is part of HM Coastguard.

Who needs to take training

Compulsory basic training (CBT) is a course you usually have to take before you ride a moped or motorcycle on the road.

Key concept: compulsory basic training required

The training makes sure you can ride safely on your own while you practise for your full moped or motorcycle test.

Key concept: training ensures safe riding while practicing for test

CBT is not a test that you pass or fail.

Key concept: CBT not pass or fail

After you’ve completed CBT, you can ride a:

  • moped if you’re 16 or over
    • Key concept: ride moped if 16 or over
  • motorcycle up to 125cc and with a power output of up to 11kW if you’re 17 or over
    • Key concept: ride motorcycle up to 125cc and 11kW if 17 or over

    You must use L plates (L or D plates in Wales).

    Key concept: use L plates

    You must pass your full moped or motorcycle test within 2 years, or you have to either take CBT again or stop riding.

    if you do not pass your full moped or motorcycle test within 2 years, you have to either take CBT again or stop riding

    You can be fined up to £1,000 and get up to 6 penalty points for riding if you do not have a valid CBT certificate.

    if you ride without a valid CBT certificate, you can be fined up to £1,000 and get up to 6 penalty points

    How the training works

    The CBT course usually lasts a full day. It can take longer depending on how quickly you learn.

    Key concept: CBT course duration is a full day

    There are 5 parts to the course:

  • introduction and eyesight check
    • Key concept: introduction and eyesight check
  • on-site training
    • Key concept: on-site training
  • on-site riding
    • Key concept: on-site riding
  • on-road training
    • Key concept: on-road training
  • on-road riding
    • Key concept: on-road riding

    The CBT course syllabus tells you more about what’s involved in each part.

    Key concept: CBT course syllabus provides details

    You move from one part to the next when your trainer is happy you’ve:

  • learnt the theory
    • Key concept: learnt the theory
  • shown the practical skills to a safe basic level
    • Key concept: shown practical skills to safe basic level

The CBT course usually lasts a full day. It can take longer depending on how quickly you learn.

Answer: yes

    You will not be able to get a Postgraduate Master’s Loan if:

    if you have been suspended but not taken off the register, you can claim compensation

    There are different rules for your ADI registration in Northern Ireland.

    Key concept: different rules in Northern Ireland

    Compensation if you stay on the register

    You can get compensation if your approved driving instructor (ADI) registration was suspended, but you were not taken off the ADI register.

    if your ADI registration was suspended but you were not taken off the ADI register, you can get compensation

    This includes cases where:

  • you win an appeal against the decision to take you off the register
    • if you win an appeal against the decision to take you off the register, you can get compensation
  • the registrar considers taking you off the register, but then ends the suspension and lets you stay on the register
    • if the registrar considers taking you off the register but then ends the suspension and lets you stay on the register, you can get compensation
  • the registrar has not made a decision about taking you off the register within 75 days
    • if the registrar has not made a decision about taking you off the register within 75 days, you can get compensation

    What you can claim

    You can claim compensation for income and non-income losses as a result of being suspended.

    you can claim compensation for income and non-income losses as a result of being suspended

    You can also claim for the cost of preparing your compensation application.

  • incurred (within reason) while you were suspended

Overview

Your approved driving instructor (ADI) registration can be suspended if the ADI registrar thinks you pose a significant threat to public safety.

Key concept: ADI registration can be suspended

The ADI registrar can suspend you if they’re considering:

  • taking you off the ADI register
    • Key concept: considering taking off ADI register
  • removing your trainee driving instructor licence
    • Key concept: considering removing trainee driving instructor licence
  • refusing to extend your registration or trainee licence
    • Key concept: considering refusing to extend registration or trainee licence

    You cannot get paid for giving driving lessons if you’re suspended.

    Key concept: cannot get paid for giving driving lessons if suspended

    Compensation if you stay on the register

    You can get compensation if your approved driving instructor (ADI) registration was suspended, but you were not taken off the ADI register.

    Key concept: compensation available if registration suspended but not taken off

    This includes cases where:

  • you win an appeal against the decision to take you off the register
    • Key concept: win appeal against decision to take off register
  • the registrar considers taking you off the register, but then ends the suspension and lets you stay on the register
    • Key concept: registrar considers taking off register but ends suspension and lets stay on register
  • the registrar has not made a decision about taking you off the register within 75 days
    • Key concept: registrar has not made decision within 75 days

    What you can claim

    You can claim compensation for income and non-income losses as a result of being suspended.

    Key concept: claim compensation for income and non-income losses

    You can also claim for the cost of preparing your compensation application.

    Key concept: claim for cost of preparing compensation application

    Income losses

    ‘Income losses’ are what you’d have got from giving driving lessons during the time you were suspended.

    Key concept: income losses are what you would have earned from giving driving lessons during suspension

    Work out your income losses

    You’ll need to work how much you’d have reasonably expected to earn during the time you were suspended.

    Key concept: work out how much you would have reasonably expected to earn during suspension

    This should be based on your income for a period that you can directly compare with, for example the same period the previous year.

    Key concept: base claim on income for a period that can be directly compared with, such as the same period the previous year

    You should base your claim on the period that best compares to the time you were suspended if you cannot directly compare with a previous year.

    Key concept: base claim on the period that best compares to the time you were suspended if unable to directly compare with a previous year

    If your claim is for a different amount to what’s shown in the previous period, you should explain why, for example a major change in how many pupils you taught in the weeks just before you were suspended.

    Key concept: explain any difference in claim amount compared to previous period, such as a major change in the number of pupils taught before suspension
inter_results.full_response:
You can claim compensation for income and non-income losses as a result of being suspended.

‘Income losses’ are what you’d have got from giving driving lessons during the time you were suspended.

You’ll need to work how much you’d have reasonably expected to earn during the time you were suspended.

This should be based on your income for a period that you can directly compare with, for example the same period the previous year.

Answer: yes

answers: An employment contract does not have to be written down.

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

All employees have an employment contract with their employer. A contract is an agreement that sets out an employee’s:

  • employment conditions
  • rights
  • responsibilities
  • duties
    • Every employee has an employment contract with their employer, which is an agreement that outlines their employment conditions, rights, responsibilities, and duties.

    These are called the ‘terms’ of the contract.

    The terms of the contract refer to these employment conditions, rights, responsibilities, and duties.

    Employees and employers must stick to a contract until it ends (for example, by an employer or employee giving notice or an employee being dismissed) or until the terms are changed (usually by agreement between the employee and employer).

    Both employees and employers are obligated to adhere to the terms of the contract until it ends, either through notice given by the employer or employee, or through the termination of the employee. The terms can also be changed, typically through mutual agreement between the employee and employer.

    If a person has an agreement to do some work for someone (like paint their house), this isn’t an employment contract but a ‘contract to provide services’.

    If a person has an agreement to perform specific work for someone, such as painting their house, it is not considered an employment contract but rather a "contract to provide services."

    Accepting a contract

    As soon as someone accepts a job offer they have a contract with their employer. An employment contract does not have to be written down.

    Once someone accepts a job offer, a contract is formed between them and their employer. It is important to note that an employment contract does not have to be in writing.

    Contract terms

    The legal parts of a contract are known as ‘terms’. An employer should make clear which parts of a contract are legally binding.

    The legal components of a contract are referred to as "terms." It is the responsibility of the employer to clearly indicate which parts of the contract are legally binding.

    Contract terms could be:

  • in a written contract, or similar document like a written statement of employment
  • verbally agreed
  • in an employee handbook or on a company notice board
  • in an offer letter from the employer
  • required by law (for example, an employer must pay employees at least the National Minimum Wage)
  • in collective agreements - negotiated agreements between employers and trade unions or staff associations
  • implied terms - automatically part of a contract even if they’re not written down
    • Contract terms can be found in a written contract, a written statement of employment, or can be verbally agreed upon. They may also be outlined in an employee handbook, on a company notice board, or in an offer letter from the employer. Additionally, certain terms may be required by law, such as the obligation for an employer to pay employees at least the National Minimum Wage. Collective agreements, which are negotiated agreements between employers and trade unions or staff associations, can also form part of the contract. Finally, there may be implied terms that are automatically considered part of the contract, even if they are not explicitly written down.
inter_results.full_response:
As soon as someone accepts a job offer they have a contract with their employer. An employment contract does not have to be written down.

Answer: An employment contract does not have to be written down.

    These are called the ‘terms’ of the contract.

    The terms of the contract refer to the employment conditions, rights, responsibilities, and duties outlined in the agreement.

    Employees and employers must stick to a contract until it ends (for example, by an employer or employee giving notice or an employee being dismissed) or until the terms are changed (usually by agreement between the employee and employer).

    Both employees and employers are obligated to adhere to the terms of the contract until it is terminated (e.g., by giving notice or dismissal) or until the terms are modified (usually through mutual agreement between the employee and employer).

    If a person has an agreement to do some work for someone (like paint their house), this isn’t an employment contract but a ‘contract to provide services’.

    If a person has an agreement to perform specific work for someone, such as painting their house, it is not considered an employment contract but rather a "contract to provide services."

    Contract terms

    The legal parts of a contract are known as ‘terms’. An employer should make clear which parts of a contract are legally binding.

    The legal components of a contract are referred to as "terms." It is the employer's responsibility to clearly indicate which parts of the contract are legally binding.

    Contract terms could be:

  • in a written contract, or similar document like a written statement of employment
  • verbally agreed
  • in an employee handbook or on a company notice board
  • in an offer letter from the employer
  • required by law (for example, an employer must pay employees at least the National Minimum Wage)
  • in collective agreements - negotiated agreements between employers and trade unions or staff associations
  • implied terms - automatically part of a contract even if they’re not written down
    • Contract terms can be documented in a written contract, a written statement of employment, or other similar documents.     • if your business is changing what it does or doing things in a different way or changing location or closing down, redundancy is possible

    Statutory redundancy pay rates

    These are based on an employee’s age and length of employment and are counted back from the date of dismissal.

    Employees get:

  • 1.5 weeks’ pay for each full year of employment after their 41st birthday
  • a week’s pay for each full year of employment after their 22nd birthday
  • half a week’s pay for each full year of employment up to their 22nd birthday

    • Length of service is capped at 20 years.

    Your employee’s weekly pay is the average they earned per week over the 12 weeks before the day they got their redundancy notice.

    If your employee earned less than usual because you used the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme to put them ‘on furlough’, you must work out their redundancy payments based on what they would have earned normally.

    Weekly pay is capped at £544. The maximum amount of statutory redundancy pay is £16,320.

    Statutory redundancy pay rates may be different in Northern Ireland.

    You can give your staff extra redundancy pay if you want to, or have a qualifying period of less than 2 years.

    You can use the redundancy pay calculator to work out payments.

Operators of seagoing ships or small commercial vessels must protect the health and safety of workers by:

  • following safety standards and codes of practice

  • ensuring the safety of machinery and equipment

  • making sure the vessel is safely manned and all workers have the necessary qualifications
    • Key concept: ensure vessel is safely manned and workers are qualified
  • having the right emergency procedures and equipment
    • Key concept: have right emergency procedures and equipment
  • providing health protection and medical care
    • Key concept: provide health protection and medical care
  • doing regular risk assessments
    • Key concept: do regular risk assessments
  • supplying necessary protective clothing and equipment

  • monitoring maritime safety information broadcasts
    • Key concept: monitor maritime safety information broadcasts
  • consulting with workers or their representatives on health and safety matters
    • Key concept: consult with workers on health and safety matters

    Risk assessments

    Regular risk assessments must be carried out to see how accidents, injuries or illnesses could be caused on the ship and what can be done to reduce the chances of them happening.

    Risk assessments must be reviewed every year and whenever there are significant changes to either the ship or working activities.

    Read the ‘Merchant Shipping and Fishing Vessels (Health and Safety at Work) Regulations 1997’ for the requirements for risk assessments on merchant ships.

    Key concept: read merchant shipping and fishing vessels regulations

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

All employees have an employment contract with their employer. A contract is an agreement that sets out an employee’s:

  • employment conditions
  • rights
  • responsibilities
  • duties
    • These are called the ‘terms’ of the contract.

    Employees and employers must stick to a contract until it ends (for example, by an employer or employee giving notice or an employee being dismissed) or until the terms are changed (usually by agreement between the employee and employer).

    If a person has an agreement to do some work for someone (like paint their house), this isn’t an employment contract but a ‘contract to provide services’.

    if a person has an agreement to do some work for someone, it is a contract to provide services, not an employment contract

    Written statement of employment particulars

    An employer must give employees and workers a document stating the main conditions of employment when they start work. This is known as a ‘written statement of employment particulars’. It is not an employment contract.

    The written statement is made up of:

  • the main document (known as a ‘principal statement’)
  • a wider written statement

    • The employer must provide the principal statement on the first day of employment and the wider written statement within 2 months of the start of employment.

    Employers must tell employees or workers about any changes to the written statement. They must do this within one month of making the change.

    There are special rules for agencies on documents that they need to provide to agency workers.

    The principal statement

    The principal statement must include at least:

  • the employer’s name
  • the employee’s or worker’s name, job title or a description of work and start date
  • how much and how often an employee or worker will get paid
  • hours and days of work and if and how they may vary (also if employees or workers will have to work Sundays, nights or overtime)
  • holiday entitlement (and if that includes public holidays)
  • where an employee or worker will be working and whether they might have to relocate
  • if an employee or worker works in different places, where these will be and what the employer’s address is
  • how long a job is expected to last (and what the end date is if it’s a fixed-term contract)
  • how long any probation period is and what its conditions are
  • any other benefits (for example, childcare vouchers and lunch)
  • obligatory training, whether or not this is paid for by the employer

    • For employees, it must also include the date that a previous job started if it counts towards a period of continuous employment.

    Working abroad

    If an employee or worker has to work outside the UK for more than a month, the principal statement must also include:

  • how long they’ll be abroad
  • what currency they’ll be paid in
  • what additional pay or benefits they’ll get
  • terms relating to their return to the UK
inter_results.full_response:
Employers must tell employees or workers about any changes to the written statement. They must do this within one month of making the change.

Answer: yes

Overview

All employees have an employment contract with their employer. A contract is an agreement that sets out an employee’s:

  • employment conditions
    • Key concept: employment conditions
  • rights
    • Key concept: rights
  • responsibilities
    • Key concept: responsibilities
  • duties
    • Key concept: duties These are called the ‘terms’ of the contract.

    Employees and employers must stick to a contract until it ends (for example, by an employer or employee giving notice or an employee being dismissed) or until the terms are changed (usually by agreement between the employee and employer).

    Key concept: contract binding until end or terms changed

    If a person has an agreement to do some work for someone (like paint their house), this isn’t an employment contract but a ‘contract to provide services’.

    if a person has an agreement to do some work for someone, it is a contract to provide services

    Contract terms

    The legal parts of a contract are known as ‘terms’. An employer should make clear which parts of a contract are legally binding.

    Key concept: legal parts of contract are terms

    Contract terms could be:

  • in a written contract, or similar document like a written statement of employment
    • Key concept: written contract or statement of employment
  • verbally agreed
    • Key concept: verbally agreed terms
  • in an employee handbook or on a company notice board
    • Key concept: employee handbook or company notice board terms
  • in an offer letter from the employer
    • Key concept: offer letter terms
  • required by law (for example, an employer must pay employees at least the National Minimum Wage)
    • Key concept: required by law terms
  • in collective agreements - negotiated agreements between employers and trade unions or staff associations
    • Key concept: collective agreements terms
  • implied terms - automatically part of a contract even if they’re not written down
    • Key concept: implied terms

    Implied terms

    If there’s nothing clearly agreed between you and your employer about a particular issue, it may be covered by an implied term - for example:

  • employees not stealing from their employer
    • Key concept: implied term of not stealing
  • your employer providing a safe and secure working environment
    • Key concept: implied term of safe working environment
  • a legal requirement like the right to a minimum of 5.6 weeks’ paid holidays
    • Key concept: implied term of minimum paid holidays
  • something necessary to do the job like a driver having a valid licence
    • Key concept: implied term of valid driver licence
  • something that’s been done regularly in a company over a long time like paying a Christmas bonus
    • Key concept: implied term of regular company practices

something that’s been done regularly in a company over a long time like paying a Christmas bonus

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

Redundancy is when you dismiss an employee because you no longer need anyone to do their job. This might be because your business is:

  • changing what it does
    • Key concept: changing what the business does
  • doing things in a different way, for example using new machinery
    • Key concept: doing things in a different way
  • changing location or closing down
    • Key concept: changing location or closing down if your business is changing what it does or doing things in a different way or changing location or closing down, it may result in redundancy

    If you’ve been impacted by coronavirus (COVID-19), you can get funding to continue to pay your employees instead of making them redundant. This is known as furloughing.

    if you have been impacted by COVID-19, you can get funding for furloughing

    For a redundancy to be genuine, you must demonstrate that the employee’s job will no longer exist.

    if the employee's job will no longer exist, the redundancy is genuine

    Redundancies can be compulsory or non-compulsory. If you do have to make redundancies you can get help from Jobcentre Plus.

    if redundancies are compulsory, you can get help from Jobcentre Plus

    If you have financial difficulties

    If your business would become insolvent as a result of making the statutory redundancy payments, the Insolvency Service’s Redundancy Payments Service (RPS) may be able to help.

    if making the statutory redundancy payments would make your business insolvent, you can get help from the Insolvency Service's Redundancy Payments Service (RPS)

  • your name

  • whether you’re the employer
    • Key concept: include whether you are the employer in the email
  • whether you should be the main point of contact
    • Key concept: include whether you should be the main point of contact in the email
  • the name of your business
    • Key concept: include the name of your business in the email
  • your business address
    • Key concept: include your business address in the email
  • number of redundancies
    • Key concept: include the number of redundancies in the email
inter_results.full_response:
If your business would become insolvent as a result of making the statutory redundancy payments, the Insolvency Service’s Redundancy Payments Service (RPS) may be able to help.

Answer: the Insolvency Service’s Redundancy Payments Service (RPS)

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

If your house or business is not connected to the mains sewer, your sewage will go to one of the following:

  • a septic tank - an underground tank where the solids sink to the bottom and the liquid flows out and soaks through the ground
  • a small sewage treatment plant (also known as a package treatment plant) - a part-mechanical system that treats the liquid so it’s clean enough to go into a river or stream
  • a cesspool (also called a cesspit) - a sealed tank that collects the sewage
  • a non-standard system, such as a reed bed or trench arch system
    • if your house or business is not connected to the mains sewer, your sewage will go to a septic tank, a small sewage treatment plant, a cesspool, or a non-standard system

    There are different rules for septic tanks and treatment plants in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

    Key concept: rules differ in Northern Ireland Key concept: rules differ in Scotland Key concept: rules differ in Wales

    If you install a new cesspool

    You must:

  • get planning permission and building regulations approval
  • make sure it has a minimum capacity of 18,000 litres per 2 users (plus another 6,800 litres per each extra user)
    • if you install a new cesspool, you must get planning permission and building regulations approval. The cesspool must have a minimum capacity of 18,000 litres per 2 users, plus another 6,800 litres per each extra user.
inter_results.full_response:
If you install a new cesspool, you must:

  • make sure it has a minimum capacity of 18,000 litres per 2 users (plus another 6,800 litres per each extra user)

Overview

If your house or business is not connected to the mains sewer, your sewage will go to one of the following:

  • a septic tank - an underground tank where the solids sink to the bottom and the liquid flows out and soaks through the ground
  • a small sewage treatment plant (also known as a package treatment plant) - a part-mechanical system that treats the liquid so it’s clean enough to go into a river or stream
  • a cesspool (also called a cesspit) - a sealed tank that collects the sewage
  • a non-standard system, such as a reed bed or trench arch system
    • if your house or business is not connected to the mains sewer, you may have a septic tank, a small sewage treatment plant, a cesspool, or a non-standard system

    There are different rules for septic tanks and treatment plants in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

    Key concept: septic tank and treatment plant rules differ in Northern Ireland Key concept: septic tank and treatment plant rules differ in Scotland Key concept: septic tank and treatment plant rules differ in Wales

    You have a septic tank or small sewage treatment plant

    As the ‘operator’ of a septic tank or small sewage treatment plant you must check you meet the general binding rules. You must apply for a permit if you do not.

    if you have a septic tank or small sewage treatment plant, you are the operator and you must check if you meet the general binding rules. If you do not meet the rules, you must apply for a permit

    You’re an operator if any of the following is true:

  • you own the property that uses the system
  • you own a property that shares the system with other properties - each property owner is an operator, and you’re jointly responsible for complying with the general binding rules
  • you have a written agreement with the property owner that says you’re responsible for the system’s maintenance, for example you’re renting and it’s in your tenancy agreement
    • if you own the property that uses the system or you own a property that shares the system with other properties or you have a written agreement with the property owner that says you’re responsible for the system’s maintenance, you are the operator

    Contact the Environment Agency if you’re not sure whether you’re an operator.

    if you are not sure whether you are the operator, contact the Environment Agency

    The general binding rules

    You must follow the general binding rules if you’re the operator of a septic tank or small sewage treatment plant.

    if you are the operator of a septic tank or small sewage treatment plant, you must follow the general binding rules

    The sewage must:

  • be domestic in nature, for example from a toilet, bathroom, shower or kitchen of a house, flat or business (such as a pub, hotel or office) - contact the Environment Agency if you’re not sure if the sewage is domestic in nature
  • not cause pollution - find out how to check for pollution
    • the sewage must be domestic in nature and must not cause pollution

    There are other rules depending on whether you’re releasing this sewage:

  • to the ground, for example in your back garden
  • to a surface water, for example a river or stream
    • if you are releasing the sewage to the ground, you must use a septic tank or a small sewage treatment plant and a drainage field (infiltration system). You must apply for a permit if you release (‘discharge’) to a well or borehole, discharge more than 2 cubic metres per day, or discharge in a Source Protection Zone 1. You must also read the additional rules for discharging sewage to the ground.

    Apply for a permit

    You’ll need a permit if you do not meet the general binding rules.

    if you do not meet the general binding rules, you will need to apply for a permit

    The form you need to fill in depends on:

  • where you discharge the sewage
  • how much you discharge
    • the form you need to fill in depends on where you discharge the sewage and how much you discharge
inter_results.full_response:
You must apply for a permit if you do not meet the general binding rules.

VAT on mobility aids

If you’re over 60, you pay a reduced rate of VAT (5%) on certain mobility aids when you pay for them to be supplied and installed in your home.

if you are over 60, you pay a reduced rate of VAT (5%) on certain mobility aids when you pay for them to be supplied and installed in your home

Qualifying products

You can get the reduced rate on:

  • grab rails
  • ramps
  • stair lifts
  • bath lifts
  • built-in shower seats or showers containing built-in shower seats
  • walk-in baths with sealable doors
    • if you are eligible for the reduced rate of VAT on mobility aids, you can get the reduced rate on grab rails, ramps, stair lifts, bath lifts, built-in shower seats or showers containing built-in shower seats, and walk-in baths with sealable doors

    You do not get the reduced rate if you repair or replace the goods after they’ve been installed.

    if you repair or replace the goods after they've been installed, you do not get the reduced rate of VAT

    You do not have to order and pay for the product yourself - a friend, local council, charity or housing association can do it for you.

    Key concept: order and payment by others allowed

    How to get the reduced rate

    Your supplier should know about the reduced rate and apply it. You qualify if:

  • you’re over 60 when the product is supplied or installed
  • the product is installed - you do not get the reduced rate if you just buy it
  • the product is for a private home, for example your own home or one shared with friends or relatives (a residential care home does not qualify)
    • if your supplier knows about the reduced rate and you are over 60 when the product is supplied or installed and the product is installed and the product is for a private home, you qualify for the reduced rate of VAT

    You’ll need to confirm to your supplier in writing that you meet these conditions. They may give you a form, or you can sign your own declaration. Ask a relative, partner or other responsible person if you’re not able to fill it in yourself.

Eligibility

You may be able to get Bereavement Support Payment (BSP) if your husband, wife or civil partner died in the last 21 months.

if your husband, wife, or civil partner died in the last 21 months, you are eligible for Bereavement Support Payment

You must claim within 3 months of your partner’s death to get the full amount. You can claim up to 21 months after their death but you’ll get fewer monthly payments.

if you claim within 3 months of your partner's death, you will receive the full amount of Bereavement Support Payment. Otherwise, you will receive fewer monthly payments.

Bereavement Support Payment has replaced Bereavement Allowance (previously Widow’s Pension), Bereavement Payment, and Widowed Parent’s Allowance.

Bereavement Support Payment has replaced Bereavement Allowance, Bereavement Payment, and Widowed Parent's Allowance

You could be eligible if your partner either:

  • paid National Insurance contributions for at least 25 weeks in one tax year since 6 April 1975
  • died because of an accident at work or a disease caused by work
    • if your partner paid National Insurance contributions for at least 25 weeks in one tax year since 6 April 1975 or died because of an accident at work or a disease caused by work, you are eligible for Bereavement Support Payment

    When they died you must have been:

  • under State Pension age
  • living in the UK or a country that pays bereavement benefits
    • if you were under State Pension age and living in the UK or a country that pays bereavement benefits when your partner died, you are eligible for Bereavement Support Payment

    You cannot claim BSP if you’re in prison.

    if you are in prison, you cannot claim Bereavement Support Payment
