inter_results.nl_code:
Writing down allowances

When you buy business assets you can usually deduct the full value from your profits before tax using annual investment allowance (AIA).

if you buy business assets, you can deduct the full value using annual investment allowance (AIA)

Use writing down allowances instead if:

  • you’ve already claimed AIA on items worth a total of more than the AIA amount
  • the item doesn’t qualify for AIA (for example, cars, gifts or things you owned before you used them in your business)
    • if you have already claimed AIA on items worth more than the AIA amount or the item doesn't qualify for AIA, use writing down allowances

    Writing down allowances is when you deduct a percentage of the value of an item from your profits each year.

    when using writing down allowances, you deduct a percentage of the value of an item from your profits each year

    The percentage you deduct depends on the item. For business cars the rate depends on their CO2 emissions.

    if the item is a business car, the deduction rate depends on its CO2 emissions

    Rates and pools

    If you’re claiming writing down allowances, group items into pools depending on which rate they qualify for.

    when claiming writing down allowances, group items into pools based on their qualifying rate

    The 3 types of pool are the:

  • main pool with a rate of 18%
  • special rate pool with a rate of 6%
  • single asset pools with a rate of 18% or 6% depending on the item
    • the main pool has a rate of 18%, the special rate pool has a rate of 6%, and the single asset pools have a rate of 18% or 6% depending on the item

    Special rate pool

    You have to claim a lower rate of 6% on:

  • parts of a building considered integral - known as ‘integral features’
  • items with a long life
  • thermal insulation of buildings
  • cars with CO2 emissions over a certain threshold - check the threshold for your car, which depends on the car and when you bought it
    • you have to claim a lower rate of 6% on parts of a building considered integral, items with a long life, thermal insulation of buildings, and cars with CO2 emissions over a certain threshold

    You can claim AIA on these items apart from cars. Only claim writing down allowances at 6% if you’ve already claimed AIA on items worth a total of more than the AIA amount.

    if the item is a car with CO2 emissions over the threshold, you can claim AIA on other items except for cars. Only claim writing down allowances at 6% if you have already claimed AIA on items worth more than the AIA amount

    Integral features

    Integral features are:

  • lifts, escalators and moving walkways
  • space and water heating systems
  • air-conditioning and air cooling systems
  • hot and cold water systems (but not toilet and kitchen facilities)
  • electrical systems, including lighting systems
  • external solar shading
    • if the item is an integral feature, it includes lifts, escalators and moving walkways, space and water heating systems, air-conditioning and air cooling systems, hot and cold water systems (but not toilet and kitchen facilities), electrical systems including lighting systems, and external solar shading

    Buildings themselves don’t qualify for capital allowances.

    buildings themselves do not qualify for capital allowances

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

Your limited company usually pays Corporation Tax on the profit (‘chargeable gain’) from selling or disposing of an asset.

Key concept: limited company pays Corporation Tax on chargeable gain

Company assets

Assets are things your company owns, such as:

  • land and property
  • equipment and machinery
  • shares
    • Key concept: company assets include land and property, equipment and machinery, and shares

    Who pays Corporation Tax

    Corporation Tax on chargeable gains is paid by:

  • limited companies
  • most unincorporated associations, for example clubs and co-operatives
  • foreign companies with a UK branch or office
    • Key concept: Corporation Tax on chargeable gains is paid by limited companies, most unincorporated associations, and foreign companies with a UK branch or office

    You pay Capital Gains Tax instead if you’re a self-employed sole trader or business partner.

    Key concept: self-employed sole traders or business partners pay Capital Gains Tax

    Work out a chargeable gain

    The gain is usually the difference between what you paid for the asset and what you sold it for.

    Key concept: gain is the difference between purchase price and sale price

    You’ll need to use the asset’s market value if your business gave it away, or sold it for less than it was worth to help the buyer.

    Key concept: use market value if asset given away or sold below value

    You can deduct any costs, for example solicitors’ fees or Stamp Duty.

    Key concept: deduct costs like solicitors' fees or Stamp Duty
inter_results.full_response:
Your limited company usually pays Corporation Tax on the profit (‘chargeable gain’) from selling or disposing of an asset.

Corporation Tax on chargeable gains is paid by:

  • limited companies

A director’s loan is when you (or other close family members) get money from your company that is not:

  • a salary, dividend or expense repayment
  • money you’ve previously paid into or loaned the company
    • if you receive money from your company that is not a salary, dividend, expense repayment, or money you've previously paid into or loaned to the company, it is considered a director's loan

    If you charge interest

    Interest you charge your company on a loan counts as both:

  • a business expense for your company
  • personal income for you
    • if you charge interest on the loan, it is considered a business expense for your company and personal income for you

    You must report the income on a personal Self Assessment tax return.

    you must report the income on your personal tax return

    Your company must:

  • pay you the interest less Income Tax at the basic rate of 20%
    • your company must pay you the interest amount minus income tax at the basic rate of 20%
  • report and pay the Income Tax every quarter using form CT61
    • your company must report and pay the income tax every quarter using form CT61

    You can request form CT61 online or call HM Revenue and Customs.

How it works

You could get a Funeral Expenses Payment (also called a Funeral Payment) if you get certain benefits and need help to pay for a funeral you’re arranging.

Key concept: eligible for Funeral Expenses Payment

This guide is also available in Welsh (Cymraeg).

Key concept: guide available in Welsh

Eligibility

You can get a Funeral Expenses Payment if all of the following apply:

  • you get certain benefits or tax credits
  • you meet the rules on your relationship with the deceased
  • you’re arranging a funeral in the UK, the European Economic Area (EEA) or Switzerland
    • if you get certain benefits or tax credits and meet the rules on your relationship with the deceased and are arranging a funeral in the UK, the European Economic Area (EEA) or Switzerland, you are eligible for Funeral Expenses Payment

    You might be able to get other help to pay for the funeral if you’re not eligible for Funeral Expenses Payment.

    if you are not eligible for Funeral Expenses Payment, you may get other help to pay for the funeral

    Benefits and tax credits you must get

    You (or your partner) must get one or more of the following:

  • Income Support
  • income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance
  • income-related Employment and Support Allowance
  • Pension Credit
  • Housing Benefit
  • the disability or severe disability element of Working Tax Credit
  • Child Tax Credit
  • Universal Credit

    • You might also be eligible if you’re getting a Support for Mortgage Interest loan.

    You can still claim Funeral Expenses Payment if you’ve applied for these benefits and you’re waiting to hear about your claim.

    If you were responsible for a deceased child but you’re not their parent, the non-resident parent must get one or more of these benefits.

    If there’s a close relative of the deceased who is not getting one of these benefits, you might not be able to claim Funeral Expenses Payment.

    if you get Income Support or income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance or income-related Employment and Support Allowance or Pension Credit or Housing Benefit or the disability or severe disability element of Working Tax Credit or Child Tax Credit or Universal Credit or Support for Mortgage Interest loan, you are eligible for Funeral Expenses Payment

    Rules on your relationship with the deceased

    You must be one of the following:

  • the partner of the deceased when they died
  • a close relative or close friend of the deceased
  • the parent of a baby stillborn after 24 weeks of pregnancy
  • the parent or person responsible for a deceased child who was under 16 (or under 20 and in approved education or training)

    • You might not get a Funeral Expenses Payment if another close relative of the deceased (such as a sibling or parent) is in work.

    if you are the partner of the deceased when they died or a close relative or close friend of the deceased or the parent of a baby stillborn after 24 weeks of pregnancy or the parent or person responsible for a deceased child who was under 16 (or under 20 and in approved education or training), you are eligible for Funeral Expenses Payment if another close relative of the deceased (such as a sibling or parent) is in work, you may not get Funeral Expenses Payment

You can get a Funeral Expenses Payment if all of the following apply:

  • you get certain benefits or tax credits
  • you meet the rules on your relationship with the deceased
  • you’re arranging a funeral in the UK, the European Economic Area (EEA) or Switzerland
    • if you get certain benefits or tax credits and meet the rules on your relationship with the deceased and are arranging a funeral in the UK, the European Economic Area (EEA) or Switzerland, you are eligible for Funeral Expenses Payment

    You might be able to get other help to pay for the funeral if you’re not eligible for Funeral Expenses Payment.

    if you are not eligible for Funeral Expenses Payment, you may get other help to pay for the funeral

    Benefits and tax credits you must get

    You (or your partner) must get one or more of the following:

  • Income Support
  • income-based Jobseeker’s Allowance
  • income-related Employment and Support Allowance
  • Pension Credit
  • Housing Benefit
  • the disability or severe disability element of Working Tax Credit
  • Child Tax Credit
  • Universal Credit

    • You might also be eligible if you’re getting a Support for Mortgage Interest loan.

    You can still claim Funeral Expenses Payment if you’ve applied for these benefits and you’re waiting to hear about your claim.

    If you were responsible for a deceased child but you’re not their parent, the non-resident parent must get one or more of these benefits.

    If there’s a close relative of the deceased who is not getting one of these benefits, you might not be able to claim Funeral Expenses Payment.

    if you get Income Support or income-based Jobseeker's Allowance or income-related Employment and Support Allowance or Pension Credit or Housing Benefit or the disability or severe disability element of Working Tax Credit or Child Tax Credit or Universal Credit or Support for Mortgage Interest loan, you are eligible for Funeral Expenses Payment

    Rules on your relationship with the deceased

    You must be one of the following:

  • the partner of the deceased when they died
  • a close relative or close friend of the deceased
  • the parent of a baby stillborn after 24 weeks of pregnancy
  • the parent or person responsible for a deceased child who was under 16 (or under 20 and in approved education or training)

    • You might not get a Funeral Expenses Payment if another close relative of the deceased (such as a sibling or parent) is in work.

    if you are the partner of the deceased when they died or a close relative or close friend of the deceased or the parent of a baby stillborn after 24 weeks of pregnancy or the parent or person responsible for a deceased child who was under 16 (or under 20 and in approved education or training), you are eligible for Funeral Expenses Payment if another close relative of the deceased (such as a sibling or parent) is in work, you may not get Funeral Expenses Payment
inter_results.full_response:
You can get a Funeral Expenses Payment if all of the following apply:

  • you get certain benefits or tax credits
  • you meet the rules on your relationship with the deceased
  • you’re arranging a funeral in the UK, the European Economic Area (EEA) or Switzerland
    • Answer: yes

For 12 months or more

You must tell DVLA if you’re taking your vehicle out of the UK, including to the Channel Islands (Jersey and Guernsey), Isle of Man or Ireland, for 12 months or more.

if you are taking your vehicle out of the UK for 12 months or more, you must notify DVLA

This is known as permanent export. You’ll need to:

  • Fill in the ‘permanent export’ section of your vehicle log book (V5C) and detach it from the log book.
    • Key concept: fill in permanent export section of vehicle log book Key concept: detach permanent export section from log book
  • Send the completed ‘permanent export’ section to DVLA, Swansea, SA99 1BD. Include a letter if you’ve moved abroad and want your vehicle tax refund (if you’re entitled to one) sent to your new address.
    • Key concept: send completed permanent export section to DVLA if you have moved abroad and want your vehicle tax refund sent to your new address, include a letter with your new address
  • Keep the rest of your log book (V5C) - you need it to register your vehicle in the country you’re taking it to.
    • Key concept: keep rest of vehicle log book
  • Update the address on your driving licence if you’re moving home.
    • if you are moving home, update the address on your driving licence

    If you’re due a refund, it will take longer than usual because of coronavirus (COVID-19). The refund is worked out from the date DVLA gets your ‘permanent export’ section.

    if you are due a refund, the processing may be delayed due to COVID-19. The refund amount is calculated from the date DVLA receives your permanent export section.

    If you’re buying a vehicle to take abroad make sure the seller follows the correct process for vehicles that will be registered in another country. They must give you the full log book (V5C) - not just the new keeper slip.

Overview

You can challenge the results of an exam or qualification if you think it’s wrong.

Key concept: can challenge exam or qualification results

Request a review

You can challenge the result of a GCSE, AS level or A level exam.

You can also challenge the result of another qualification.

Key concept: can challenge GCSE, AS level, A level exams Key concept: can challenge other qualification

Who can request a GCSE, AS level or A level review

You can ask your school or college to get an exam result looked at again (known as ‘requesting a review’). You cannot request a review yourself unless you’re a private candidate, for example you were home schooled.

if you are a private candidate, you can request a review

What happens next

The mark will be changed if the reviewer thinks it’s wrong. The new mark may be higher or lower than the original.

Key concept: mark will be changed if reviewer thinks it's wrong Key concept: new mark may be higher or lower

You can ask your school or college’s exams officer for more information about their internal appeals procedure and their policy on reviews of marking and moderation.

Key concept: ask exams officer for appeals procedure and policy

You can appeal against a review if you’re unhappy with the decision.

Key concept: can appeal against review

You or your school may have to pay if the mark is not changed.

if the mark is not changed, you or your school may have to pay
inter_results.full_response:
You can challenge the result of a GCSE, AS level or A level exam.

You can ask your school or college to get an exam result looked at again (known as ‘requesting a review’). You cannot request a review yourself unless you’re a private candidate, for example you were home schooled.

The electoral register (sometimes called the ‘electoral roll’) lists the names and addresses of everyone who’s registered to vote.

Key concept: electoral register lists names and addresses

Use the register to vote service to:

  • get on the electoral register
    • Key concept: get on electoral register
  • update your details (for example change your name or address)

    To check whether you’re already on the register, contact:

  • your local Electoral Registration Office if you live in England, Scotland or Wales
    • Key concept: contact local Electoral Registration Office in England, Scotland or Wales
  • the Electoral Office for Northern Ireland (EONI) if you live in Northern Ireland
    • Key concept: contact Electoral Office for Northern Ireland

    Opt out of the 'open register'

    There are 2 versions of the electoral register - the full version and the ‘open register’ (known as the ‘edited register’ in Northern Ireland).

    Key concept: two versions of electoral register

    If you registered to vote anonymously your details will not appear on either version of the electoral register. You will still be able to vote.

    if you registered to vote anonymously, your details will not appear on either version of the electoral register. However, you will still be able to vote.

    How to opt out of the open register

    You can opt out of the open register. This is the version of the register that’s available to anyone who wants to buy a copy.

    Key concept: opt out of open register

    To opt out, either:

  • use the register to vote service (even if you’re already registered)
    • Key concept: use register to vote service
  • contact your local Electoral Registration Office if you live in England, Scotland or Wales
    • Key concept: contact local Electoral Registration Office in England, Scotland or Wales
  • contact the Electoral Office for Northern Ireland (EONI) if you live in Northern Ireland
    • Key concept: contact Electoral Office for Northern Ireland

    Opting out does not affect your right to vote.

    Key concept: opting out does not affect right to vote

    When you opt out of the open register, your details will still appear on the full version of the electoral register.

    Key concept: details appear on full version of register when opt out of open register

  • Gift Aid repayments on donations

    • if your sports club is eligible, you can become a community amateur sports club (CASC) and get tax relief on income, gains and profits from some activities, Gift Aid repayments on donations, and business rates relief

    To benefit you must register with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).

    You can claim relief on money you use to promote and provide facilities for eligible sports. These are known as ‘qualifying purposes’.

    • Key concept: managed by fit and proper persons

    Open to the whole community

    CASCs must be open to people of all ethnicities, nationalities, sexual orientations, religions or beliefs, sexes, ages and ability - except when a certain level of physical ability is needed to take part in a sport.

    Key concept: open to whole community except for physical ability requirement

    Organised on an amateur basis

    CASCs must:

  • not make a profit, unless this is reinvested in the club and spent only on promoting participation and providing facilities for eligible sports
    • Key concept: not make profit unless reinvested in club
  • not pay more than £10,000 in total to all players in a year (before 1 April 2015 CASCs couldn’t pay players at all)
    • Key concept: not pay more than £10,000 to players in a year
  • provide only the benefits normally associated with an amateur sports club, eg use of equipment, coaching, post-match refreshments
    • Key concept: provide benefits associated with amateur sports club
  • only pay expenses for matches and tours where players take part in and promote the club’s sport (before 1 April 2015 clubs couldn’t pay any expenses)
    • Key concept: only pay expenses for matches and tours where players take part and promote sport
inter_results.full_response:
To register as a CASC you must provide facilities for eligible sports and encourage people to take part. Under the new rules from 1 April 2015, at least 50% of members must take part.

Answer: yes

  • your local Electoral Registration Office if you live in England, Scotland or Wales

    Key concept: valid reason for not registering

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

You may be able to get help with the cost of term-time accommodation if you’re studying a further education course that’s far from your home.

if you are studying a further education course that is far from your home, you may be eligible for help with term-time accommodation

How much you get depends on your household income.

Key concept: grant amount depends on household income

You will not be able to get help with boarding school fees.

Key concept: cannot get help with boarding school fees

Residential Bursary Fund

You may be able to get help with the cost of accommodation from the Residential Bursary Fund (RBF).

Key concept: eligible for help from Residential Bursary Fund

Eligibility

You must:

  • meet the residency requirements (your college will check this)
  • be at least 16 and under 19 on 31 August 2021
    • if you meet the residency requirements and are between 16 and 19 years old on 31 August 2021, you are eligible for the Residential Bursary Fund

    You may be eligible if you’re 19 and either:

  • continuing on a course you started aged 16 to 18
  • have an education, health and care plan (EHCP)
    • if you are 19 years old and either continuing on a course you started aged 16 to 18 or have an education, health and care plan (EHCP), you may be eligible for the Residential Bursary Fund

    Your course must:

  • be at a specialist residential centre (your college can confirm this)
  • be too far to travel to each day (your college must agree with this)
  • be full-time
  • be ‘16 to 19 funded’ (your college can confirm this)
    • if your course is at a specialist residential centre, is too far to travel to each day, is full-time, and is '16 to 19 funded', you are eligible for the Residential Bursary Fund

    What you’ll get

    Your college will decide how much you get. It depends on your household income.

    Key concept: college decides grant amount based on household income

    You can get payments for a maximum of 3 years.

    Key concept: maximum payment duration is 3 years

    Eligibility

    You must:

  • be at least 16 and under 19 on 31 August 2021
  • meet the residency requirements (your college will check this)
  • not be on housing benefit
  • have a household income of less than £30,993
  • be studying your first level 2 or level 3 qualification (for example 2 or more A levels, a diploma or a national vocational qualification)
    • if you are between 16 and 19 years old on 31 August 2021, meet the residency requirements, are not on housing benefit, have a household income of less than £30,993, and are studying your first level 2 or level 3 qualification, you are eligible for the grant

    Your course must:

  • not be at a specialist residential centre (your college can confirm this)
  • be full-time at a college in England
  • be ‘16 to 19 funded’ (your college can confirm this)
    • if your course is not at a specialist residential centre, is full-time at a college in England, and is '16 to 19 funded', you are eligible for the grant

    Your course must also be more than either 15 miles or a 2 hour round trip from your home, and not available any closer than that.

    if your course is more than 15 miles or a 2 hour round trip from your home and not available any closer than that, you are eligible for the grant

    What you’ll get

    The table shows the maximum you can get each year. The actual amount you can get depends on your accommodation costs.

    Gross household income | Studying outside London | Studying in London Up to £21,000 | Up to £3,458 | Up to £4,079 £21,001 to £25,704 | Up to £2,305 | Up to £2,685 £25,705 to £30,993 | Up to £1,152 | Up to £1,355 £30,994 or more | No award | No award if you are studying outside London, the maximum grant amount is as follows: - Up to £3,458 if your household income is up to £21,000 - Up to £2,305 if your household income is between £21,001 and £25,704 - Up to £1,152 if your household income is between £25,705 and £30,993 - No award if your household income is £30,994 or more if you are studying in London, the maximum grant amount is as follows: - Up to £4,079 if your household income is up to £21,000 - Up to £2,685 if your household income is between £21,001 and £25,704 - Up to £1,355 if your household income is between £25,705 and £30,993 - No award if your household income is £30,994 or more

    You can get payments for a maximum of 3 years.

    Key concept: maximum payment duration is 3 years
inter_results.full_response:
You may be able to get help with the cost of term-time accommodation if you’re studying a further education course that’s far from your home.

How much you get depends on your household income.

You will not be able to get help with boarding school fees.

You may be able to get help with the cost of accommodation from the Residential Bursary Fund (RBF).

Your college will decide how much you get. It depends on your household income.

You can get payments for a maximum of 3 years.

You must be at least 16 and under 19 on 31 August 2021.

Your course must be full-time and '16 to 19 funded'.

Your course must be more than either 15 miles or a 2-hour round trip from your home, and not available any closer than that.

The maximum grant amount depends on your household income and whether you are studying outside London or in London.

Answer: It depends.

Overview

You can challenge your solicitor’s bill if you think you’ve been charged too much.

Key concept: can challenge solicitor's bill

Ask the Senior Courts Costs Office to make a ‘detailed assessment’ of your bill. They can reduce your bill if they agree it’s too expensive.

There’s a different process if you want to complain about your solicitor’s behaviour.

Key concept: complain about solicitor's behaviour

How to apply

Download and fill in 3 copies of Part 8 claim form (N208). You must pay £45.

Key concept: download and fill in 3 copies of Part 8 claim form Key concept: pay £45

Send a cheque made payable to ‘HMCTS’ with all 3 copies of your completed form and a copy of your solicitor’s bill to:

Key concept: send cheque with copies of form and solicitor's bill

You can apply to your local District Registry (a court that deals with certain High Court cases) instead if you live outside of London.

Key concept: apply to local District Registry if outside London

Apply to your nearest county court if the original case was dealt with by a county court and your solicitor’s bill is for £5,000 or less.

Key concept: apply to nearest county court if original case dealt with by county court and solicitor's bill is £5,000 or less

inter_results.nl_code:
For 12 months or more

You must tell DVLA if you’re taking your vehicle out of the UK, including to the Channel Islands (Jersey and Guernsey), Isle of Man or Ireland, for 12 months or more.

if you are taking your vehicle out of the UK for 12 months or more, you must notify DVLA of the permanent export

This is known as permanent export. You’ll need to:

  • Fill in the ‘permanent export’ section of your vehicle log book (V5C) and detach it from the log book.
    • Key concept: fill in permanent export section of vehicle log book Key concept: detach permanent export section from log book
  • Send the completed ‘permanent export’ section to DVLA, Swansea, SA99 1BD. Include a letter if you’ve moved abroad and want your vehicle tax refund (if you’re entitled to one) sent to your new address.
    • Key concept: send completed permanent export section to DVLA if you have moved abroad and want your vehicle tax refund sent to your new address, include a letter with your new address
  • Keep the rest of your log book (V5C) - you need it to register your vehicle in the country you’re taking it to.
    • Key concept: keep rest of vehicle log book
  • Update the address on your driving licence if you’re moving home.
    • if you are moving home, update the address on your driving licence

    If you’re due a refund, it will take longer than usual because of coronavirus (COVID-19). The refund is worked out from the date DVLA gets your ‘permanent export’ section.

    if you are due a refund, there may be a delay in processing it due to COVID-19

    If you’re buying a vehicle to take abroad make sure the seller follows the correct process for vehicles that will be registered in another country. They must give you the full log book (V5C) - not just the new keeper slip.

    if you are buying a vehicle to take abroad, ensure that the seller provides you with the full log book (V5C)

    Before you leave the UK

    You need to get a vehicle log book (V5C) before you leave the UK. DVLA cannot send a vehicle log book to an address outside the UK.

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

Anything posted or couriered to you from another country goes through customs to check it is not banned or restricted and you pay the right tax and ‘duty’ on it.

if you receive anything posted or couriered from another country, it goes through customs to ensure it is not banned or restricted and to determine the correct tax and duty to be paid

This includes anything new or used that you:

  • buy online
  • buy abroad and send back to the UK
  • receive as a gift
    • if you buy online, buy abroad and send back to the UK, or receive as a gift, it is subject to customs checks and tax and duty payment

    Your responsibilities

    Before receiving your goods, you may have to pay VAT, Customs Duty or Excise Duty if they were sent to:

  • Great Britain (England, Wales and Scotland) from outside the UK
  • Northern Ireland from countries outside the UK and the European Union (EU)
    • if the goods were sent to Great Britain from outside the UK or to Northern Ireland from countries outside the UK and the EU, you may have to pay VAT, Customs Duty, or Excise Duty

    You must also check that the sender:

  • pays Excise Duty on any alcohol or tobacco sent from the EU to Northern Ireland
  • declares goods correctly if they’re sent from outside the UK (or from outside the EU for Northern Ireland)
    • you must ensure that the sender pays Excise Duty on alcohol or tobacco sent from the EU to Northern Ireland and that goods are declared correctly if sent from outside the UK or from outside the EU for Northern Ireland

    Your goods may be seized if you do not follow the rules. You may also be fined or prosecuted.

    if you do not follow the rules, your goods may be seized and you may face fines or prosecution

    Tax and duty

    You’ll be contacted by Royal Mail, Parcelforce or the courier company if you need to pay any VAT, duty or delivery charges (‘handling fees’) to receive your goods.

    you will be contacted by Royal Mail, Parcelforce, or the courier company to pay VAT, duty, or delivery charges to receive your goods

    They’ll send you a bill stating exactly which fees you need to pay.

    you will receive a bill stating the fees you need to pay

    They’ll normally hold your parcel for about 3 weeks. If you have not paid the bill by then, your parcel will be returned to the sender.

    the delivery company will hold your parcel for approximately 3 weeks. If you do not pay the bill within that time, your parcel will be returned to the sender

    You will not have to pay anything to the delivery company to receive goods worth less than £135 unless they’re gifts over £39 or excise goods (for example, alcohol and tobacco).

    you do not have to pay anything to the delivery company for goods worth less than £135, unless they are gifts over £39 or excise goods

    VAT

    VAT is charged on all goods (except for gifts worth £39 or less) sent from:

  • outside the UK to Great Britain
  • outside the UK and the EU to Northern Ireland
    • VAT is charged on goods sent from outside the UK to Great Britain and from outside the UK and the EU to Northern Ireland

    VAT is not charged on goods that are gifts worth £39 or less.

    VAT is not charged on gifts worth £39 or less

    You pay VAT when you buy the goods or to the delivery company before you receive them. If you have to pay VAT to the delivery company, it’s charged on the total package value, including:

    VAT is paid when buying the goods or to the delivery company before receiving them. If you have to pay VAT to the delivery company, it is charged on the total package value, including:
  • the value of the goods
  • postage, packaging, and insurance
  • any duty you owe

    • VAT is charged at the VAT rate that applies to your goods.

    VAT is charged at the applicable rate for your goods

    Goods worth £135 or less in total

    If you bought the goods yourself and they are not excise goods, the seller will have included VAT in the total you paid.

    if you bought the goods yourself and they are not excise goods, the seller will have included VAT in the total amount you paid

    You will need to pay VAT to the delivery company if the goods are:

  • gifts sent to you by someone else and worth more than £39
  • excise goods
    • you will need to pay VAT to the delivery company for gifts sent by someone else and worth more than £39, as well as for excise goods

    Customs Duty

    You’ll be charged Customs Duty on all goods sent from outside the UK (or the UK and the EU if you’re in Northern Ireland) if they’re either:

  • excise goods
  • worth more than £135
    • you will be charged Customs Duty on goods sent from outside the UK or the UK and the EU if you're in Northern Ireland if they are either excise goods or worth more than £135

    If you’re charged Customs Duty, you’ll need to pay it on both:

  • the price paid for the goods
  • postage, packaging, and insurance
    • if you are charged Customs Duty, you will need to pay it on the price paid for the goods as well as on postage, packaging, and insurance Type and value of goods | Customs Duty Non-excise goods worth £135 or less | No charge Gifts above £135 and up to £630 | 2.5%, but rates are lower for some goods - call the helpline Gifts above £630 and other goods above £135 | The rate depends on the type of goods and where they came from - call the helpline Customs Duty is not charged for non-excise goods worth £135 or less. For gifts above £135 and up to £630, the rate is 2.5%, but rates may be lower for some goods. For gifts above £630 and other goods above £135, the rate depends on the type of goods and their origin - you can call the helpline for more information.

    You pay Customs Duty on excise goods of any value.

    you pay Customs Duty on excise goods regardless of their value

    Excise Duty

    If you’re sent alcohol or tobacco from outside the UK, you’ll be charged Excise Duty at current rates.

    Calculate VAT taxable turnover

    VAT taxable turnover is the total value of everything you sell that is not exempt from VAT.

    You must register for VAT with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) if it goes over the current registration threshold in a rolling 12-month period. This is not a fixed period like the tax year or the calendar year - it could be any period, for example the start of June to the end of May.

    The current threshold is £85,000. It usually goes up on 1 April each year. If your business is based in Northern Ireland, there are different thresholds for buying and selling from EU countries.

    if your VAT taxable turnover goes over the threshold in a rolling 12-month period, you must register for VAT

    What to include

    To check if you’ve gone over the threshold in any 12-month period, add together the total value of your UK sales that are not VAT exempt, including:

  • goods you hired or loaned to customers
  • business goods used for personal reasons
  • goods you bartered, part-exchanged or gave as gifts
  • services you received from businesses in other countries that you had to ‘reverse charge’
  • building work over £100,000 your business did for itself

    • Include any zero-rated items - only exclude VAT-exempt sales, and goods or services you supply outside of the UK.

Overview

Anything posted or couriered to you from another country goes through customs to check it is not banned or restricted and you pay the right tax and ‘duty’ on it.

if something is posted or couriered to you from another country, it goes through customs to check if it is banned or restricted and to determine the tax and duty you need to pay

This includes anything new or used that you:

  • buy online
  • buy abroad and send back to the UK
  • receive as a gift
    • if you buy something online, buy something abroad and send it back to the UK, or receive something as a gift, it goes through customs

    Your responsibilities

    Before receiving your goods, you may have to pay VAT, Customs Duty or Excise Duty if they were sent to:

  • Great Britain (England, Wales and Scotland) from outside the UK
  • Northern Ireland from countries outside the UK and the European Union (EU)
    • if the goods were sent to Great Britain from outside the UK or to Northern Ireland from countries outside the UK and the EU, you may have to pay VAT, Customs Duty, or Excise Duty

    You must also check that the sender:

  • pays Excise Duty on any alcohol or tobacco sent from the EU to Northern Ireland
  • declares goods correctly if they’re sent from outside the UK (or from outside the EU for Northern Ireland)
    • you must check that the sender pays Excise Duty on alcohol or tobacco sent from the EU to Northern Ireland and declares goods correctly if they're sent from outside the UK or from outside the EU for Northern Ireland

    Your goods may be seized if you do not follow the rules. You may also be fined or prosecuted.

    if you do not follow the rules, your goods may be seized and you may be fined or prosecuted

    VAT

    VAT is charged on all goods (except for gifts worth £39 or less) sent from:

  • outside the UK to Great Britain
  • outside the UK and the EU to Northern Ireland
    • VAT is charged on all goods sent from outside the UK to Great Britain and from outside the UK and the EU to Northern Ireland, except for gifts worth £39 or less

    VAT is not charged on goods that are gifts worth £39 or less.

    VAT is not charged on goods that are gifts worth £39 or less

    You pay VAT when you buy the goods or to the delivery company before you receive them. If you have to pay VAT to the delivery company, it’s charged on the total package value, including:

    you pay VAT when you buy the goods or to the delivery company before you receive them. If you have to pay VAT to the delivery company, it's charged on the total package value, including the value of the goods, postage, packaging and insurance, and any duty you owe

    VAT is charged at the VAT rate that applies to your goods.

    VAT is charged at the applicable rate for your goods

    Goods worth £135 or less in total

    If you bought the goods yourself and they are not excise goods, the seller will have included VAT in the total you paid.

    if the goods are worth £135 or less in total and you bought them yourself and they are not excise goods, the seller will have included VAT in the total you paid

    You will need to pay VAT to the delivery company if the goods are:

  • gifts sent to you by someone else and worth more than £39
  • excise goods
    • you will need to pay VAT to the delivery company if the goods are gifts sent to you by someone else and worth more than £39 or if they are excise goods
inter_results.full_response:

  • outside the UK to Great Britain
  • outside the UK and the EU to Northern Ireland

You’ll probably need planning permission if you want to:

  • build something new
  • make a major change to a building
  • change the use of a building
    • if you want to build something new, make a major change to a building, or change the use of a building, you will likely need planning permission

    To find out if your project will need planning permission, contact your local planning authority (LPA) through your local council.

    Key concept: planning system information available for Scotland Key concept: planning system information available for Wales Key concept: planning system information available for Northern Ireland

    After you apply

    Your local planning authority (LPA) will decide whether to grant planning permission for your project based on its development plan. It will not take into account whether local people want it.

    Key concept: LPA decides planning permission based on development plan

  • the number, size, layout, siting, and external appearance of buildings

  • the infrastructure available, such as roads and water supply
    • Key concept: consider available infrastructure
  • any landscaping needs
    • Key concept: consider landscaping needs
  • what you want to use the development for
    • Key concept: consider purpose of development
  • how your development would affect the surrounding area - for example, if it would create lots more traffic
    • Key concept: consider impact on surrounding area

    In most cases, planning applications are decided within 8 weeks. In England, for unusually large or complex applications, the time limit is 13 weeks. If the decision takes longer, you can appeal.

    You must register if, by the end of any month, your total VAT taxable turnover for the last 12 months was over £85,000.

If your house or business is not connected to the mains sewer, your sewage will go to one of the following:

  • a cesspool (also called a cesspit) - a sealed tank that collects the sewage

  • to the ground, for example in your back garden

Complain about an adviser

You can complain to the Office of the Immigration Services Commissioner (OISC) about either:

  • bad service you received from an adviser registered with OISC
  • immigration advice you received from an unregulated person
    • Key concept: complain about bad service from registered adviser Key concept: complain about immigration advice from unregulated person

    You can also ask someone to make a complaint on your behalf, for example a friend, solicitor or voluntary organisation.

    Key concept: complaint on behalf of someone else allowed

    There’s a different way to complain about a legal adviser registered with a professional body but not regulated by OISC.

    Key concept: complain about legal adviser registered with professional body not regulated by OISC

    What you can and cannot complain about

    You can complain about:

  • poor advice or service
    • Key concept: complain about poor advice or service
  • unreasonable fees
    • Key concept: complain about unreasonable fees
  • an adviser claiming you’ll be successful
    • Key concept: complain about adviser claiming success
  • an adviser charging for work not done
    • Key concept: complain about adviser charging for work not done
  • an adviser missing deadlines or failing to appear in court
    • Key concept: complain about adviser missing deadlines or failing to appear in court
  • an adviser
    • Key concept: complain about adviser

    You cannot make a complaint about:

  • how long your immigration application has taken
    • Key concept: cannot complain about application processing time
  • something that’s already part of an ongoing legal action
    • Key concept: cannot complain about ongoing legal action
  • a refund or compensation
    • Key concept: cannot complain about refund or compensation
  • Home Office staff
    • Key concept: cannot complain about Home Office staff
  • a person or organisation outside the UK
    • Key concept: cannot complain about person or organisation outside the UK

    You usually cannot make a complaint about something that happened more than 12 months ago - OISC will decide whether or not to investigate depending on the situation.

    Key concept: complaint time limit of 12 months

    OISC may refer your complaint elsewhere if you complain about a solicitor or barrister.

    Key concept: complaint about solicitor or barrister may be referred elsewhere

    Read more about how the OISC deals with complaints.

    Key concept: read more about OISC complaint process

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

You must apply for asylum if you want to stay in the UK as a refugee.

Key concept: apply for asylum

To be eligible you must have left your country and be unable to go back because you fear persecution.

if you have left your country and fear persecution, you are eligible for asylum

Apply for a visa if you want to come to the UK for another reason (for example to work, study or remain with family). If you’re already in the UK and want to remain with family living here, apply for a family of a settled person visa.

Key concept: apply for visa for other reasons Key concept: apply for family of a settled person visa

You should apply when you arrive in the UK or as soon as you think it would be unsafe for you to return to your own country. Your application is more likely to be denied if you wait.

if you arrive in the UK or it is unsafe for you to return to your own country, you should apply for asylum as soon as possible

When you apply you’ll have a meeting with an immigration officer (known as a ‘screening’).

Key concept: meeting with immigration officer (screening)

After your screening the Home Office will decide if your claim can be considered in the UK. If it can, you’ll have an asylum interview with a caseworker.

if your claim can be considered in the UK, you'll have an asylum interview with a caseworker

You’ll usually get a decision on your application within 6 months.

Key concept: decision within 6 months

You can get up to 2 years in prison or have to leave the UK if you give false information on your application.

if you give false information on your application, you can get up to 2 years in prison and may have to leave the UK

Your ARC

The ARC shows you’ve applied for asylum. You can use it to:

  • show who you are
    • Key concept: show identity with ARC
  • show whether you have permission to work
    • Key concept: show permission to work with ARC
  • get health or education services
    • Key concept: get health or education services with ARC

    You must take your ARC with you when you go to your reporting meetings.

if you have left your country and fear persecution, you are eligible for asylum

Apply for a visa if you want to come to the UK for another reason (for example to work, study or remain with family). If you’re already in the UK and want to remain with family living here, apply for a family of a settled person visa.

Key concept: apply for visa for other reasons Key concept: apply for family of a settled person visa

You should apply when you arrive in the UK or as soon as you think it would be unsafe for you to return to your own country. Your application is more likely to be denied if you wait.

Key concept: apply when you arrive or when unsafe to return

Key concept: screening with immigration officer

After your screening the Home Office will decide if your claim can be considered in the UK. If it can, you’ll have an asylum interview with a caseworker.

if your claim can be considered, you'll have an asylum interview with a caseworker

Eligibility

To stay in the UK as a refugee you must be unable to live safely in any part of your own country because you fear persecution there.

if you are unable to live safely in any part of your own country due to fear of persecution, you are eligible to stay as a refugee

If you’re stateless, your own country is the country you usually live in.

if you are stateless, your own country is the country you usually live in

This persecution must be because of:

  • your race
  • your religion
  • your nationality
  • your political opinion
  • anything else that puts you at risk because of the social, cultural, religious or political situation in your country, for example, your gender, gender identity or sexual orientation
    • if the persecution is due to your race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or anything else that puts you at risk because of the social, cultural, religious, or political situation in your country, you are eligible for asylum

    You must have failed to get protection from authorities in your own country.

    if you have failed to get protection from authorities in your own country, you are eligible for asylum

    When your claim might not be considered

    Your claim might not be considered if you:

  • are from an EU country
  • travelled to the UK through a ‘safe third country’
  • have a connection to a safe third country where you could claim asylum
    • if you are from an EU country or travelled to the UK through a 'safe third country' or have a connection to a safe third country where you could claim asylum, your claim might not be considered

    Generally, a safe third country is one that:

  • you’re not a citizen of
  • you would not be harmed in
  • would not send you on to another country where you would be harmed
    • if the conditions of a safe third country are met, your claim might not be considered

When you register, you’ll be sent a VAT registration certificate. This confirms:

  • your VAT number
  • when to submit your first VAT Return and payment
  • your ‘effective date of registration’ - this depends on the date you went over the threshold, or is the date you asked to register if it was voluntary
    • if you register your business for VAT, you will be sent a VAT registration certificate that confirms your VAT number, when to submit your first VAT Return and payment, and your effective date of registration

    You can register voluntarily if your turnover is less than £85,000, unless everything you sell is exempt. You’ll have certain responsibilities if you register for VAT.

    You can reclaim the VAT you’ve paid on certain purchases made before you registered.

    you can reclaim the VAT you've paid on certain purchases made before you registered for VAT

    Purchases made before registration

    There’s a time limit for backdating claims for VAT paid before registration. From your date of registration the time limit is:

  • 4 years for goods you still have, or that were used to make other goods you still have
  • 6 months for services
    • the time limit for backdating claims for VAT paid before registration is 4 years for goods you still have or that were used to make other goods you still have, and 6 months for services

    You can only reclaim VAT on purchases for the business now registered for VAT. They must relate to your ‘business purpose’. This means they must relate to VAT taxable goods or services that you supply.

    you can only reclaim VAT on purchases for the business that is now registered for VAT. These purchases must relate to your business purpose, which means they must relate to VAT taxable goods or services that you supply

    You should reclaim them on your first VAT Return (add them to your Box 4 figure) and keep records including:

  • invoices and receipts
  • a description and purchase dates
  • information about how they relate to your business now
    • you should reclaim the VAT on these purchases on your first VAT Return by adding them to your Box 4 figure. Additionally, you should keep records including invoices and receipts, a description and purchase dates, and information about how they relate to your business now.

follow the general binding rules

You must use a small sewage treatment plant. You must apply for a permit if you’re discharging more than 5 cubic metres (5,000 litres) per day.

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

If your house or business is not connected to the mains sewer, your sewage will go to one of the following:

  • a septic tank - an underground tank where the solids sink to the bottom and the liquid flows out and soaks through the ground
  • a small sewage treatment plant (also known as a package treatment plant) - a part-mechanical system that treats the liquid so it’s clean enough to go into a river or stream
  • a cesspool (also called a cesspit) - a sealed tank that collects the sewage
  • a non-standard system, such as a reed bed or trench arch system
    • if your house or business is not connected to the mains sewer, your sewage will go to a septic tank, a small sewage treatment plant, a cesspool, or a non-standard system

    There are different rules for septic tanks and treatment plants in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

    Key concept: septic tank and treatment plant rules differ in Northern Ireland Key concept: septic tank and treatment plant rules differ in Scotland Key concept: septic tank and treatment plant rules differ in Wales

    The general binding rules

    You must follow the general binding rules if you’re the operator of a septic tank or small sewage treatment plant.

    Key concept: follow general binding rules

    The sewage must:

  • be domestic in nature, for example from a toilet, bathroom, shower or kitchen of a house, flat or business (such as a pub, hotel or office) - contact the Environment Agency if you’re not sure if the sewage is domestic in nature
    • Key concept: sewage must be domestic in nature
  • not cause pollution - find out how to check for pollution
    • Key concept: sewage must not cause pollution

    There are other rules depending on whether you’re releasing this sewage:

inter_results.nl_code:
Overview

You must apply for asylum if you want to stay in the UK as a refugee.

Key concept: apply for asylum

To be eligible you must have left your country and be unable to go back because you fear persecution.

if you have left your country and fear persecution, you are eligible for asylum

Apply for a visa if you want to come to the UK for another reason (for example to work, study or remain with family). If you’re already in the UK and want to remain with family living here, apply for a family of a settled person visa.

Key concept: apply for visa for other reasons Key concept: apply for family of a settled person visa

You should apply when you arrive in the UK or as soon as you think it would be unsafe for you to return to your own country. Your application is more likely to be denied if you wait.

Key concept: apply as soon as possible

When you apply you’ll have a meeting with an immigration officer (known as a ‘screening’).

Key concept: screening with immigration officer

After your screening the Home Office will decide if your claim can be considered in the UK. If it can, you’ll have an asylum interview with a caseworker.

if your claim can be considered in the UK, you'll have an asylum interview with a caseworker

You’ll usually get a decision on your application within 6 months.

Key concept: decision within 6 months

You can get up to 2 years in prison or have to leave the UK if you give false information on your application.

if you give false information on your application, you can get up to 2 years in prison or may have to leave the UK

If your case cannot be considered in the UK

You may be sent to a safe country that will consider your asylum claim. This might happen if you’ve travelled to the UK through a safe third country or you have a connection with another country that you could claim asylum in.

if your case cannot be considered in the UK, you may be sent to a safe country

Generally, a safe country is one that:

  • you’re not a citizen of
  • you would not be harmed in
  • would not send you on to another country where you would be harmed
    • Key concept: safe country criteria

    The Home Office can decide to send you to a safe country after either your screening or your asylum interview.

    if you are sent to a safe country, it can happen after either your screening or your asylum interview

    If the Home Office cannot place you in another safe country, your case will be considered in the UK and given to a caseworker.

    if the Home Office cannot place you in another safe country, your case will be considered in the UK and given to a caseworker
inter_results.full_response:
If the Home Office cannot place you in another safe country, your case will be considered in the UK and given to a caseworker.

Answer: your case will be considered in the UK and given to a caseworker
